page.title: List of international presidential trips made by Joko Widodo

revision.text:
[[File:Jokowi Foreign Visits.svg|thumb|261px|Map of international trips made by Joko Widodo as President:{{legend|#4242ff|Visited}} {{legend|#ff4242|Indonesia}}]] {{Joko Widodo series}} This is a '''list of international presidential trips made by [[Joko Widodo]]''' (Jokowi), the 7th [[President of Indonesia]]. He assumed presidency on 20 October 2014. As of October 2018, Jokowi had visited 32 countries. ==2014== {{multiple image |align=center |image1=Vladimir Putin and Joko Widodo, November 2014.jpg |caption1=Jokowi meeting [[Vladimir Putin]] in the [[APEC China 2014|APEC Summit]] |image2=PM Modi and Indonesian President Joko Widodo at Nay Pyi Taw, Myanmar.jpg |caption2=Jokowi meeting [[Narendra Modi]] in [[Naypyidaw]] }} {| class="wikitable outercollapse sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 15%;"|Dates !style="width: 17%;"|Country !style="width: 15%;"|Locations !style="width: 96%;"|Details |- |8-12 November |{{CHN}} |[[Beijing]] |Jokowi attended [[APEC China 2014]] as his first international conference.{{cite news |last1=Witular |first1=Rendi A. |last2=Widhiarto |first2=Hasyim |title=Jokowi on world stage, first stop Beijing |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/11/09/jokowi-world-stage-first-stop-beijing.html |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=The Jakarta Post |date=9 November 2014}}{{cite news |title=Hari Ke-20 Jokowi-JK: Lawatan Perdana ke Luar Negeri |url=https://nasional.kompas.com/read/2015/01/29/10474401/Hari.Ke-20.Jokowi-JK.Lawatan.Perdana.ke.Luar.Negeri |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=KOMPAS |date=29 January 2015 |language=id}} |- |12-13 November |{{MYA}} |[[Naypyidaw]] |Jokowi attended his first [[ASEAN Summit]], in addition to the China-ASEAN conference.{{cite web |title=Presiden Jokowi Tekankan Kerja Sama Ekonomi dan Maritim dalam Kemitraan ASEAN-RRT |url=https://www.kemlu.go.id/id/berita/siaran-pers/Pages/Presiden-Jokowi-Tekankan-Kerja-Sama-Ekonomi-dan-Maritim-dalam-Kemitraan-ASEAN-RRT.aspx |website=kemlu.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=14 November 2014}} |- |14-16 November |{{AUS}} |[[Brisbane]] |Jokowi attended his first [[2014 G20 Brisbane summit|G20 summit]]. |} ==2015== {{multiple image |align=center |image1=Benigno S. Aquino III shakes hand with Joko Widodo.jpg |caption1 = Jokowi with [[Benigno Aquino III]] in [[Malacañan Palace]] |image2=Jokowi Xi Jinping 2015.jpg |caption2 = Jokowi with [[Xi Jinping]] |image3=The President Holds a Bilateral Meeting with the President of Indonesia.webm |caption3=Jokowi with [[Barack Obama]] in the [[White House]] }} {| class="wikitable outercollapse sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 15%;"|Dates !style="width: 17%;"|Country !style="width: 15%;"|Locations !style="width: 96%;"|Details |- |5-7 February |{{MAS}} |[[Putrajaya]] |Jokowi attended bilateral talks with Malaysian PM [[Najib Razak]] to discuss maritime borders and cooperation in addition to Indonesian students and workers in Malaysia.{{cite news |title=Jokowi puas hati, sifatkan lawatan ke Malaysia berjaya - Duta Indonesia |url=http://www.astroawani.com/berita-dunia/jokowi-puas-hati-sifatkan-lawatan-ke-malaysia-berjaya-duta-indonesia-53525 |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Astro Awani |date=7 February 2015 |language=ms}}{{cite news |last1=Sari |first1=Amanda Puspita |title=Wartawan Malaysia Dilarang Meliput Kunjungan Jokowi |url=https://www.cnnindonesia.com/internasional/20150207143636-106-30350/wartawan-malaysia-dilarang-meliput-kunjungan-jokowi |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=CNN Indonesia |date=7 February 2015 |language=id}} |- |7-8 February |{{BRU}} |[[Bandar Seri Begawan]] |Jokowi attended bilateral talks with Sultan [[Hassanal Bolkiah]], discussing cooperation in trade, labor and defense.{{cite web |title=Inilah Hasil Kunjungan Presiden Jokowi ke Brunei Darussalam |url=http://setkab.go.id/inilah-hasil-kunjungan-presiden-jokowi-ke-brunei-darussalam/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=7 February 2015}} |- |8-10 February |{{PHI}} |[[Manila]] |Jokowi attended bilateral talks with President [[Benigno Aquino III]], discussing maritime boundaries, cooperation in security, education and economics, in addition to protection of citizens and migrant workers.{{cite news |last1=Cabacungan |first1=Gil C. |title=Widodo PH visit boosts Aquino |url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/118526/widodo-ph-visit-boosts-aquino |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=The Inquirer |date=10 February 2015}} |- |22-25 March |{{JAP}} |[[Tokyo]] |Jokowi visited Japan to engage in talks with PM [[Shinzo Abe]] regarding economic cooperation, specifically infrastructure development.{{cite web |title=Disambut Udara Dingin, Presiden Jokowi Tiba di Tokyo Untuk Kunjungan Kenegaraan |url=http://setkab.go.id/disambut-udara-dingin-presiden-jokowi-tiba-di-tokyo-untuk-kunjungan-kenegaraan/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=22 March 2015}} |- |25-28 March |{{CHN}} |[[Beijing]]
[[Sanya]], [[Hainan]] |Jokowi conducted bilateral talks with [[Xi Jinping]] in Beijing, discussing economic cooperation and infrastructure development in addition to requesting a visa exemption for Indonesian citizens visiting China.{{cite news |title=Jokowi Minta Fasilitas Bebas Visa untuk WNI ke Cina |url=https://www.dw.com/id/jokowi-minta-fasilitas-bebas-visa-untuk-wni-ke-cina/a-18345293 |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=27 March 2015 |language=id}} He then went to [[Sanya]] to conduct bilateral meetings with Dutch PM [[Mark Rutte]] and become a keynote speaker.{{cite web |title=Tiba di Hainan, Presiden Jokowi Bersiap Jadi Pembicara Kunci Pada Boao Forum Asia |url=http://setkab.go.id/tiba-di-hainan-presiden-jokowi-bersiap-jadi-pembicara-kunci-pada-boao-forum-asia/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=27 March 2015}} |- |28-29 March |{{MAS}} |[[Kuala Lumpur]] |Jokowi attended the wedding of Malaysian PM [[Najib Razak]]'s daughter.{{cite web |title=Mampir ke Malaysia, Presiden Jokowi Hadiri Resepsi Pernikahan Putri PM Najib |url=http://setkab.go.id/mampir-ke-malaysia-presiden-jokowi-hadiri-resepsi-pernikahan-putri-pm-najib/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id}} |- |29 March |colspan=2|{{SIN}} |Jokowi attended the [[Death of Lee Kuan Yew|funeral]] of former Singaporean PM [[Lee Kuan Yew]].{{cite news |title=Jokowi Hadiri Kremasi Lee Kuan Yew |url=http://www.tribunnews.com/nasional/2015/03/29/jokowi-hadiri-kremasi-lee-kuan-yew |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Tribunnews.com |date=29 March 2015 |language=id-ID}} |- |26-27 April |{{MAS}} |[[Kuala Lumpur]] |Jokowi attended an [[ASEAN Summit]].{{cite news |title=Indonesia’s Foreign Minister Calls for Code of Conduct in South China Sea |url=https://jakartaglobe.id/news/indonesias-foreign-minister-calls-for-code-of-conduct-in-south-china-sea/ |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Jakarta Globe |date=27 April 2015 |language=id}} |- |11-12 May |{{PNG}} |[[Port Moresby]] |Jokowi signed agreements on cross-border crime, human resources cooperation, and economic cooperation with PNG PM [[Peter O'Neill]].{{cite web |title=Inilah Kesepakatan Kerjasama Yang Dicapai Dalam Kunjungan Presiden Jokowi Ke PNG |url=http://setkab.go.id/inilah-kesepakatan-kerjasama-yang-dicapai-dalam-kunjungan-presiden-jokowi-ke-png/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=12 May 2015}} |- |28-29 July |colspan=2|{{SIN}} |Jokowi met Singaporean president [[Tony Tan Keng Yam]] and PM [[Lee Hsien Loong]] to discuss economic cooperation.{{cite web |title=Press Release Kunjungan Kenegaraan Presiden Jokowi ke Singapura |url=https://www.kemlu.go.id/id/berita/siaran-pers/Pages/Press-Release-Kunjungan-Kenegaraan-Presiden-Jokowi-ke-Singapura.aspx |website=kemlu.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=27 July 2015}} |- |11-13 September |{{SAU}} |[[Jeddah]] |Jokowi arrived just after the [[Mecca crane collapse]] which killed 11 Indonesians, and held a press conference upon landing. The bilateral talks with [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|King Salman]] involved defense cooperation, hajj affairs, investment, and a request of clemency for 4 Indonesians on death row.{{cite news |last1=Rimadi |first1=Luqman |title=Kunjungan Istimewa Jokowi di Timur Tengah |url=https://www.liputan6.com/news/read/2318318/kunjungan-istimewa-jokowi-di-timur-tengah |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=liputan6.com |date=16 September 2015 |language=id}}{{cite news |title=FOTO: Kunjungan Jokowi ke Arab Saudi |url=https://www.rappler.com/indonesia/105729-foto-kunjungan-jokowi-arab-saudi |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Rappler |date=13 September 2015 |language=id}} |- |13-14 September |{{UAE}} |[[Abu Dhabi]]
[[Dubai]] |Jokowi met with crown prince [[Mohammed Bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] in [[Abu Dhabi]] and discussed investment.{{cite web |title=Tiba Di Abu Dhabi, Presiden Jokowi Disambut Putra Mahkota UEA |url=http://setkab.go.id/tiba-di-abu-dhabi-presiden-jokowi-disambut-putra-pangeran-uea/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=13 September 2015}} Later, he went to [[Dubai]] for a working visit.{{cite web |title=Kunjungan Kerja Presiden RI Joko Widodo ke Dubai |url=https://www.kemlu.go.id/dubai/id/berita-agenda/berita-perwakilan/Pages/Kunjungan-Kerja-Presiden-RI-Joko-Widodo-ke-Dubai.aspx |website=kemlu.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id}} |- |14-15 September |{{QAT}} |[[Doha]] |Jokowi met with Qatari businessmen and urged them to invest in Indonesia.{{cite web |title=Bertemu Pengusaha Qatar, Presiden Jokowi: Saat Ini Waktu Yang Tepat Investasi Di Indonesia |url=http://setkab.go.id/bertemu-pengusaha-qatar-presiden-jokowi-saat-ini-waktu-yang-tepat-investasi-di-indonesia/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=15 September 2015}} |- |25-28 October |{{USA}} |[[Washington, D.C.]]
[[San Francisco]] |Jokowi conducted bilateral talks with US President [[Barack Obama]] in the [[White House]] regarding investment and religious tolerance, issuing a joint statement on maritime, defense, economic and energy cooperation, before heading to meet business and academic leaders in San Francisco.{{cite web |title=25 – 28 Oktober, Presiden Jokowi Akan Berkunjung Ke AS |url=http://setkab.go.id/25-28-oktober-presiden-jokowi-akan-berkunjung-ke-as/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id}}{{cite web |title=Joint Statement by the United States of America and the Republic of Indonesia |url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2015/10/26/joint-statement-united-states-america-and-republic-indonesia |website=whitehouse.gov |accessdate=12 October 2018 |date=26 October 2015}} |- |15-16 November |{{TUR}} |[[Antalya]] |Jokowi participated in the [[2015 G20 Antalya summit]], holding talks with [[Xi Jinping]] and newly elected [[Justin Trudeau]].{{cite web |title=Hujan Lebat di Jakarta Sambut Kedatangan Presiden Jokowi dari Turki |url=http://setkab.go.id/hujan-lebat-di-jakarta-sambut-kedatangan-presiden-jokowi-dari-turki/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id}} |- |30 November-2 December |{{FRA}} |[[Paris]] |Jokowi attended the [[COP 21]], where he gave a speech committing to reducing Indonesia's emission by 29 percent in 2030 (or 41 percent with international support), and increasing renewable energy shares to 23 percent by 2025.{{cite web |last1=Setiawan |first1=Alfurkon |title=President Jokowi: Indonesia Commits Reducing Emission by 29% |url=http://setkab.go.id/en/president-jokowi-indonesia-commits-reducing-emission-by-29/ |website=setkab.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id}} |} ==2016== {{multiple image |align=center |image1=Jokowi and Sundar Pichai Googleplex.jpg |caption1 = Jokowi with Google CEO [[Sundar Pichai]] in [[Googleplex]] |image2=Macri with Widodo.jpg |caption2 = Jokowi with Argentinian president [[Mauricio Macri]] during the [[2016 G20 Hangzhou summit|G20 summit]] }} {| class="wikitable outercollapse sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !style="width: 15%;"|Dates !style="width: 17%;"|Country !style="width: 15%;"|Locations !style="width: 96%;"|Details |- |26 January |{{ETM}} |[[Dili]] |Jokowi met with East Timorese PM [[Rui Maria de Araujo]] and President [[Taur Matan Ruak]].{{cite web |title=Agenda Presiden Sehari di Timor Leste: Dari Blusukan sampai Ketemu Warga Indonesia |url=http://presidenri.go.id/berita-aktual/agenda-presiden-sehari-di-timor-leste-dari-blusukan-sampai-ketemu-warga-indonesia.html |website=presidenri.go.id |accessdate=12 October 2018 |language=id |date=26 January 2016}} |- |15-17 February |{{USA}} |[[California]] |Jokowi attended the ASEAN-US Summit and visited tech companies in [[Silicon Valley]].{{cite news |last1=Kusumadewi |first1=Anggi |title=Presiden Jokowi Tiba di California Amerika Serikat |url=https://www.cnnindonesia.com/nasional/20160215095759-20-110904/presiden-jokowi-tiba-di-california-amerika-serikat |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=CNN Indonesia |date=15 February 2016 |language=id}} |- |17-19 April |{{GER}} |[[Berlin]] |Jokowi met German president [[Joachim Gauck]] and chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] to discuss investment and labor training, before speaking in the German-Indonesian business forum.{{cite news |last1=Iqbal |first1=M. |title=Melihat Lebih Jelas Hasil Kunjungan Presiden Jokowi ke Eropa |url=https://news.detik.com/berita/d-3195804/melihat-lebih-jelas-hasil-kunjungan-presiden-jokowi-ke-eropa?single=1 |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=detiknews |date=25 April 2016 |language=id}} |- |19-21 April |{{GBR}} |[[London]] |Jokowi met British PM [[David Cameron]]. |- |21-22 April |{{BEL}} |[[Brussels]] |Jokowi visited the [[European Union]] office and met with its leaders [[Martin Schulz]], [[Donald Tusk]] and [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] to discuss the Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement and trade affairs, before meeting CEOs from Nordic countries and attending a reception by King [[Philippe of Belgium]]. |- |22-23 April |{{flag|Netherlands}} |[[Amsterdam]]
[[Leiden]]
[[Rotterdam]] |Jokowi met with PM [[Mark Rutte]] and discussed water management, maritime affairs, trade and investment. He also visited the [[University of Leiden]] and [[Port of Rotterdam]]. |- |15-17 May |{{KOR}} |[[Seoul]] |Jokowi fulfilled an invitation by president [[Park Geun-Hye]] and discussed about South Korea being a partner in accelerating Indonesian industrialization.{{cite news |title=Apa saja agenda Jokowi di Korea Selatan dan Rusia? |url=https://www.rappler.com/indonesia/133737-agenda-kunjungan-jokowi-korea-selatan-rusia |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Rappler |date=20 May 2016 |language=id}} |- |18-20 May |{{RUS}} |[[Sochi]] |Jokowi attended the ASEAN-Russia summit, in addition to meeting with Russian president [[Vladimir Putin]] and several Russian businessman. |- |26-27 May |{{JPN}} |[[Shima, Mie]] |Jokowi was invited as a guest to the [[42nd G7 summit]].{{cite news |last1=Agustina |first1=Widiarsi |title=Presiden Jokowi Tiba di Jepang untuk G7 Outreach |url=https://nasional.tempo.co/read/774363/presiden-jokowi-tiba-di-jepang-untuk-g7-outreach |accessdate=12 October 2018 |work=Tempo |date=26 May 2016 |language=id-ID}} |- |2-6 September |{{CHN}} revision.comment: IMA - CNMNC Master List of Minerals - added source reference "IMAMineralsCount"
revision.text:
{{short description|List of minerals, intended to be as complete as possible}} [[Mineralogy]] is an active science in which [[mineral]]s are discovered or recognised on a regular basis. Use of old mineral names is also discontinued, for example when a name is no longer considered valid. Therefore, a list of recognised mineral species is never complete. Minerals are distinguished by various chemical and physical properties. Differences in chemical composition and crystal structure distinguish the various ''species''. Within a mineral species there may be variation in physical properties or minor amounts of impurities that are recognized by mineralogists or wider society as a mineral ''variety''. The [[International Mineralogical Association]] (IMA) is the international group that recognises new minerals and new mineral names. However, minerals discovered before 1959 did not go through the official naming procedure. Some minerals published previously have been either confirmed or discredited since that date. This list contains a mixture of mineral names that have been approved since 1959 and those mineral names believed to still refer to valid mineral species (these are called "grandfathered" species). Presently, each year about 50-60 new mineral species are officially approved by the Commission on New Minerals, Nomenclature and Classification (CNMNC) of the International Mineralogical Association.{{Cite journal |journal=Elements |year=2007 |volume=3 |page=360 |url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/missingminerals.doc |title=Missing Minerals}} The IMA/CNMNC administrates c. 6,500 names,[http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/imalist.htm List of minerals] and {{As of|2018|01|lc=y}}, the Handbook of Mineralogy lists 4,507 species.{{cite web | url=http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/index.html | title=Handbook of Mineralogy | publisher=Mineralogical Society of America | accessdate=1 March 2018 | authors=John W. Anthony, Richard A. Bideaux, Kenneth W. Bladh, and Monte C. Nichols (editors)}} {{As of|2018|03}}, the IMA Database of Mineral Properties/ Rruff Project lists 5,312 valid species (IMA/CNMNC) of a total of 5,525 minerals. There are 1,289 Pre-IMA minerals.{{Cite web |url=http://rruff.info/ima/ |title=IMA Database of Mineral Properties/ RRUFF Project |accessdate=1 March 2018 |publisher=Department of Geosciences, University of Arizona }} {{As of|2011|04}}, the Webmineral.com lists 2,722 published and approved (IMA/CNMNC) minerals, 81 discredited minerals (IMA/CNMNC status; Michael Fleischer discredited around thousand species in his lifetime), 2,691 synonyms and 123 "not approved" names.[http://www.webmineral.com/Alphabetical_Listing.shtml A to Z Listing of Minerals] {{As of|2018|11}}, the IMA - CNMNC Master List of Minerals lists 5,389 valid minerals,{{cite web | url=http://nrmima.nrm.se//imalist.htm | title=The New IMA List of Minerals – A Work in Progress | publisher=[[International Mineralogical Association|IMA]] – CNMNC (Commission on New Minerals Nomenclature and Classification) | work=The New IMA List of Minerals | date=September 2018 | accessdate=2 November 2018 | author=Pasero, Marco et al.}} including c. 1,166 pre-IMA minerals (grandfathered), c. 272 approved minerals but without a published description yet and c. 99 questionable minerals. Due to the length of this list, it is divided into alphabetical groups. The minerals are sorted by name. {{col-begin}}{{col-break}} * [[List of minerals A (complete)]] * [[List of minerals B (complete)]] * [[List of minerals C (complete)]] * [[List of minerals D (complete)]] * [[List of minerals E (complete)]] * [[List of minerals F (complete)]] * [[List of minerals G (complete)]] * [[List of minerals H (complete)]] * [[List of minerals I (complete)]] * [[List of minerals J (complete)]] * [[List of minerals K (complete)]] {{col-break}} * [[List of minerals L (complete)]] * [[List of minerals M (complete)]] * [[List of minerals N (complete)]] * [[List of minerals O (complete)]] * [[List of minerals P–Q (complete)]] * [[List of minerals R (complete)]] * [[List of minerals S (complete)]] * [[List of minerals T (complete)]] * [[List of minerals U–V (complete)]] * [[List of minerals W–X (complete)]] * [[List of minerals Y–Z (complete)]] {{col-break}} * [[List of minerals (synonyms)]] * English Wikipedia:
[[List of minerals|List of minerals (short list)]] {{col-end}} * Abbreviations: **"*" – discredited (IMA/CNMNC status). **"s.p." – special procedure. **Q or "?" – questionable/doubtful (IMA/CNMNC, mindat.org or mineralienatlas.de status). **N – published without approval of the IMA/CNMNC, or just not an IMA approved mineral but with some acceptance in the scientific community nowadays. The 'IMA database of mineral properties' (rruff.info/ima) has 173 species with 'not an IMA approved mineral' tag, some are an intermediate member of a [[solid solution]] series, others are "recently" discredited minerals. **I – intermediate member of a solid-solution series. **H – hypothetical mineral (synthetic, anthropogenic, etc.) ***ch – incomplete description, hypothetical solid solution end member. Published without approval and formally discredited or not approved, yet. **** Mainly: [[pyrochlore]], [[tourmaline]] and [[amphibole]] supergroups, [[List of minerals (synonyms)#Arrojadite group|arrojadite]], and [[yftisite-(Y)]]. IMA/CNMNC revisions generate hypothetical solid solution [[endmember]]s. **group – a name used to designate a group of species, sometimes only a mineral group name. == Clockwork == * The name of a new mineral is an IMA secret until it is approved or until its full description is published, its authors' option (approved decision: 'IMA2009-D').{{cite web|title=Minerals approved in 2010|url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/newminerals2010.pdf|publisher=IMA/ CNMNC|accessdate=10 March 2012}} The IMA uses a code for its own procedures for the supposed new mineral (and so it is a synonym). Ferri-ottoliniite's proposal was assigned code 'IMA2001-067', it was redefined and approved as 'IMA2001-067a' in 2003, for instance (the ottoliniite root name is discredited since 2012). * Current IMA regulations do not allow substances of anthropogenic origin (burning coal mine dumps, coal mine fires, slag, etc.) to be validated as a mineral species. Since 1998, the majority of [[polymorphism (materials science)|polymorph]]s (especially polytypes and polytypoids) are not regarded as separate mineral species anymore.{{Cite journal |journal=The Canadian Mineralogist |title=The IMA Commission on New Minerals and Mineral Names: Procedures and Guidelines on Mineral Nomenclature, 1998 |year=1998 |last1=Nickel |first1=Ernest H. |last2=Grice |first2=Joel D. |volume=36 |url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/cnmmn98.pdf}} * IMA/CNMNC identifiers are usually written without space, as years don't get meaningful hits on Google search. * "The System of Mineralogy of James Dwight Dana and Edward Salisbury Dana" (8 ed.) was the reference of CNMNC/CNMMN's (IMA) initial work. At the [[Kobe]] 2006 general meeting, the IMA council endorsed the creation of an Internet site on minerals ('rruff.info/ima'). So a Master List was needed and the older minerals were reviewed in a document of 130 pages. The final GQN List was published (grandfathered, questionable and published without approval) after a final review of Burke E A J and Nickel E H (approved decision: 'IMA2006-C'). Not only the well established minerals before 1959 was grandfathered (G), but the minerals that could not be discredited as well. The merging of the 'ARD List' (approved, revalidated and discredited) with the 'GQN List' resulted in the first 'IMA/CNMNC List of Mineral Names'. The 2007 draft of the 'IMA/CNMNC List of Mineral Names' was a courtesy of the Materials Data, Inc. (MDI), its 2009 review had important modifications.{{Cite book |authors=Nickel E H, Nichols M C |year=2007 |title=IMA/CNMNC List of Mineral Names : draft |publisher=Materials Data, Inc. |url=http://rruff.info/rruff_1.0/uploads/MINERALlist.pdf}}{{Cite book |authors=Nickel E H, Nichols M C |year=2009 |title=IMA/CNMNC List of Mineral Names |publisher=Materials Data, Inc. |url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/IMA2009-01%20UPDATE%20160309.pdf}} The RRUFF database was built with the help of the MDI's 2007 draft, the IMA Master List is an update of the MDI's 2009 review.{{Cite web |publisher=RRUFF Database |url=http://rruff.info/about/about_IMA_list.php |title=IMA Mineral List}}{{Cite journal |author=Burke E A J |year=2006 |title=A mass discreditation of GQN minerals |journal=The Canadian Mineralogist |volume=44 |pages=1557–1560 |doi=10.2113/gscanmin.44.6.1557}}{{Cite journal |first=Jeffrey |last=de Fourestier |journal=The Canadian Mineralogist |title=The Naming of Mineral Species Approved by the Commission on New Minerals and Mineral Names of the International Mineralogical Association: A Brief History |volume=40 |pages=1721–1735 |year=2002 |doi=10.2113/gscanmin.40.6.1721}} Some grandfathered minerals had their status changed to approved afterwards, based on IMA approved reports. Note: the list of approved minerals was revised with 'The New IMA List of Minerals (September 2012)'.{{Cite web |publisher=IMA-CNMNC |url=http://nrmima.nrm.se//IMA_Master_List_(2012-09).pdf |title=The New IMA List of Minerals (September 2012)}} * The IMA was founded in a meeting in Madrid (1958). The CNMMN (now CNMNC) was one of the original eight commissions, it was founded in 1959. Not all grandfathered mineral were first described prior to 1959. [[Hatrurite]], a phase in cement clinker ([[alite]], C3S), was first described in 1977, for instance.[http://www.mindat.org/min-1828.html MinDat - Hatrurite] * Some mineral names were revised; this changed their first letters. Sodium-pharmacosiderite is now [[natropharmacosiderite]], natroapophyllite is now [[fluorapophyllite]]-(Na), for instance.{{Cite journal |author=Levinson A A |year=1966 |title=A system of nomenclature for rare-earth minerals |journal=American Mineralogist |volume=51 |pages=152–158 }}{{Cite journal |last=Nickel |first=E H |last2=Mandarino |first2=J A |authorlink=Ernest Henry Nickel |year=1987 |title=Procedures involving the IMA Commission on New Minerals and Mineral Names and guidelines on mineral nomenclature |journal=American Mineralogist |volume=72 |pages=1031–1042}}{{Cite journal |author=Burke E A J |authorlink=Ernst A. J. Burke |year=2008 |title=Tidying up mineral names: an IMA-CNMNC scheme for suffixes, hyphens and diacritical marks |journal=The Mineralogical Record |volume=39 |pages=131–135 |url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/tidyingupnames.pdf }}{{Cite journal |last=Armbruster |first=Thomas |authorlink=Thomas Armbruster |doi=10.1127/0935-1221/2002/0014-0389 |year=2002 |title=Revised nomenclature of högbomite, nigerite, and taafeite minerals |journal=European Journal of Mineralogy |volume=14 |pages=389–395 |url=http://www.krist.unibe.ch/pdf/2002/hognomen.pdf }}{{cite journal|last=Bindi|first=L|author2=Evain M |author3=Spry P G |author4=Menchetti S |title=The pearceite-polybasite group of minerals: crystal chemistry and new nomenclature rules|journal=American Mineralogist|year=2007|volume=92|pages=918–925|doi=10.2138/am.2007.2440}}{{Cite journal |journal=American Mineralogist |volume=96 |pages=895–913 |year=2011 |title=Nomenclature of the tourmaline-supergroup minerals |author1=Darrell J. Henry |author2=Milan Novák |author3=Frank C. Hawthorne |author4=Andreas Ertl |author5=Barbara L. Dutrow |author6=Pavel Uher |author7=Federico Pezzotta |last-author-amp=yes |doi=10.2138/am.2011.3636 |url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/henry%20et%20al%202011%20tourmaline%20tomenclature.pdf }}{{Cite journal |authors=Frédéric Hatert, Stuart J. Mills, Marco Pasero and Peter A. Williams |title=CNMNC guidelines for the use of suffixes and prefixes in mineral nomenclature, and for the preservation of historical names |url=http://pubsites.uws.edu.au/ima-cnmnc/Hatert%20et%20al%20CNMNC%20guidelines%20for%20suffixes%20(2).pdf |journal=European Journal of Mineralogy |volume=25 |year=2013 |pages=113–115 |doi=10.1127/0935-1221/2013/0025-2267}} But 2010, [[hydroxylapatite]], [[fluorapatite]], [[fluorellestadite]] and [[chlorapatite]] had their old names reinstated.{{Cite journal |vauthors=Pasero M, Kampf AR, Ferraris C, Pekov IV, Rakovan JR, White TJ |year=2010 |title=Nomenclature of the apatite supergroup minerals |journal=European Journal of Mineralogy |volume=22 |pages=163–179 |doi=10.1127/0935-1221/2010/0022-2022}} *Everything is slower on [[earth science]]s, [[geology]], [[mineralogy]]: ** [[Georgius Agricola]]'s [[De re metallica]] libri xii though apparently finished in 1550, was published 1556 (the author died 1555). ** Some IMA/CNMNC (1959–2000) approved minerals had their complete description published only 2012: 'IMA1998-018' ([[fluornatromicrolite]], published 2011), 'IMA1987-046a' ([[ferrolaueite]], published 2012), 'IMA1978-064' (approval probably based on fake data), 'IMA1977-006' ([[whelanite]], published 2012) and 'IMA1968-003' (discredited, 'IMA2008-B'). 'IMA1995-025' was listed as well, a mistake ([[natroglaucocerinite]], published 1995). ** The paper of Armbruster et al. (2006) misunderstood the naming rules and renamed a well established mineral name ([[hancockite]]).{{Cite journal |authors=Armbruster T, Bonazzi P, Akasaka M, Bermanec V, Chopin C, Giere R, Huess-Assbichler S, Liebscher A, Menchetti S, Pan Y, Pasero M |year=2006 |title=Recommended nomenclature of epidote-group minerals |journal=European Journal of Mineralogy |volume=18 |pages=551–567 |doi=10.1127/0935-1221/2006/0018-0551}} Hatert et al. (2013) modified the naming rules.{{Cite journal |authors=Hatert F, Mills S J, Pasero M, Williams P A |year=2013 |title=CNMNC guidelines for the use of suffixes and prefixes in mineral nomenclature, and for the preservation of historical names |journal=European Journal of Mineralogy |volume=25 |pages=113–115 |doi=10.1127/0935-1221/2013/0025-2267}} and proposal IMA2015 s.p. was accepted, reverting the renaming.{{Cite journal |authors=Hålenius U, Hatert F, Pasero M, Mills S J |year=2015 |title=IMA Commission on New Minerals, Nomenclature and Classification (CNMNC) Newsletter 26. New minerals and nomenclature modifications approved in 2015 |journal=Mineralogical Magazine |volume=79 |pages=941–947 |doi=10.1180/minmag.2015.079.4.05}} ** Sample: [[bergenite]] was discredited as a barium bearing mineral variety of [[phosphuranylite]] (IMA1962 s.p., special procedure). So phosphuranylite was already a valid mineral, and it is listed in the [[Michael Fleischer (mineralogist)|Michael Fleischer]]'s mineral list (1966).{{Cite journal |author=Michael Fleischer |journal=American Mineralogist |issue=8 |date=August 1966 |title=Index of New Mineral Names, Discredited Minerals, and Changes of Mineralogical Nomenclature in Volumes 1-50 of The American Mineralogist |pages=1247–1336}} Both are listed as grandfathered minerals as they are not listed in the 'ARD List' (approved, revalidated and discredited minerals; 2004).{{Cite web |publisher=IMA-CNMNC |url=http://nrmima.nrm.se//IMA_Master_List_2015-05.pdf |title=Master List of IMA-approved minerals (May 2015)}}{{Cite web |publisher=Aleph Enterprises |authors=Ernest Nickel and Monte Nichols |url=http://rruff.info/data_files/sample/file_1669.pdf |title=Mineral Names, Redefinitions & Discreditations Passed by the CNMMN of the IMA |date=9 February 2004}} ** The review and approval of new mineral is straight forward most of the time, but there are exceptions. Proposal IMA2009-096 was not accepted, proposal IMA2009-096a was approved as [[fontarnauite]] (6.DA.60) in 2014. Proposal IMA1995-020 was not accepted, proposal IMA1995-020c was approved as [[jarandolite]] (6.CB.25). ** Every year some valid names get discredited (in the broader sense). *** Tohdite (hydrous alumina) was conditionally approved as 'IMA2004-051'. But the re-examination of the holotype material of [[akdalaite]] ((Al2O3)5·H2O, 'IMA1969-002') from the [[Fersman Mineralogical Museum]] in Moscow showed that both minerals were identical ([[space group]] was corrected).[http://www.mindat.org/min-29353.html Mindat.org - Tohdite] *** Tellurocanfieldite was conditionally approved as 'IMA2012-013'. Its approval was withdrawn as further studies showed it to be a Te-rich variety of [[canfieldite]] (Y: 1894, 2.BA.70).[http://www.mindat.org/min-42786.html Mindat.org - Tellurocanfieldite] * Some old minerals were known before their 20th century names were first published. == Curiosities == * Current regulations do not allow a new mineral name to honour a person a second time. But there are exceptions: [[Jöns Jakob Berzelius]] (1779–1848) ([[berzelianite]], [[berzeliite]] and berzeline (now [[haüyne]])); [[Pierre Berthier]] (1782–1861) ([[berthierine]] and [[berthierite]]); [[Andor von Semsey]] (1833–1923) ([[andorite]] IV, andorite VI and [[semseyite]]); [[Brian Harold Mason]] (1917–2009) ([[brianite]] and [[stenhuggarite]]); [[Caleb Wroe Wolfe]] (1908–1980) ([[wolfeite]] and [[wroewolfeite]]) and [[Leo Neal Yedlin]] (1908–1977) ([[yedlinite]] and [[nealite]]). The regulation does not affect mineral series and other variations (prefix iso, hexa, ortho, tetra, clino, meta, para, pseudo etc.). For instance: [[Karl Hugo Strunz]] (1910–2006) ([[strunzite]] group); [[George P. Merrill]] (1854–1929) ([[merrillite]] series, [[whitlockite]] group); [[Edward S. Grew]] (Ph.D. 1971) ([[edgrewite]] series, [[humite]] group). *[[Standard temperature and pressure]] (STP). ** [[Silicate perovskite]]s, [[argentite]] and β-quartz are not valid minerals, as they do not occur on Earth's surface (STP). The type material of [[bridgmanite]] is from a meteorite. Some minerals are unstable on Earth's surface ([[metastability]]): [[diamond]]s, [[cohenite]] and [[haxonite]], for instance. [[Acanthite]] var. argentite (a [[pseudomorph]] after argentite) and β-quartz pseudomorphs are sometimes sold.[http://www.mineralienatlas.de/lexikon/index.php/MineralData?lang=en&language=english&mineral=Argentit Argentit (German)] **[[Paul Ramdohr|Ramdohr]] (1936) discovered that the [[Type material (mineralogy)|type material]] of [[schapbachite]] (Ag0.4Pb0.2Bi0.4S) was a mixture of [[galena]] (PbS) and [[matildite]] (AgBiS2).[http://www.mindat.org/min-3558.html Mindat.org - Schapbachite] It was discredited (1982) as it was found unstable at 'standard temperature and pressure' (STP).{{Cite journal |first=M H|last=Hey|year=1982 |journal=Mineralogical Magazine |title=International Mineralogical Association: Commission on New Minerals and Mineral Names |volume=46|pages=513–514 |doi=10.1180/minmag.1982.046.341.25}} It was revalidated (2004) as Pb-bearing schabachite is stable at STP.{{Cite journal|authors=Walenta K, Bernhardt H J, Theye T |year=2004 |title=Cubic AgBiS2 (schapbachite) from the Silberbrünnle mine near Gengenbach in the [[Central Black Forest]], Germany |journal=Neues Jahrbuch für Mineralogie, Monatshefte 2004 |pages=425–432 }} The [[type locality (geology)|type locality]] is not Schapbach now, but Silberbrünnle mine, Gengenbach; both [[Black Forest]] localities. **[[Hexaferrum|Epsilon iron]], [[hexagonal close-packed]] (HCP) phase of iron is stable only at extremely high pressure. It can be found as a mineral (chemical formula: (Fe,Os,Ru,Ir)). * It is not only schapbachite that had a longer controversy. Other minerals have a complicated history, as well. ** [[Imogolite]], 9.ED.20, was first published 1962.{{cite journal |last1=Yoshinaga|first1=N.|last2=Aomine|first2=S.|title=Allophane in some Ando soils|journal=Soil Science and Plant Nutrition|year=1962|volume=8|issue=2|pages=6–13|url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110001719463/en|doi=10.1080/00380768.1962.10430983}}{{cite journal |last1=Yoshinaga |first1=N. |last2=Aomine |first2=S. |title=Imogolite in some Ando soils |journal=Soil Science and Plant Nutrition |year=1962 |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=22–29 |doi=10.1080/00380768.1962.10430993 |url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/naid/110001719472}} Its formal discreditation by the IMA was published 1967, as its description was incomplete.{{Cite journal |last=Hey |first=M.H. |authorlink=Maxwell Hutchison Hey |title=International Mineralogical Association: Commission on New Minerals and Mineral Names|url=http://rruff.info/rruff_1.0/uploads/MM36_131.pdf |journal=Mineralogical Magazine|year=1967|volume=36|page=133 |doi=10.1180/minmag.1967.036.277.20}} The IMA referred it to the AIPEA (''Association Internationale Pour l'Étude des Argiles'') for advice and it was approved by the AIPEA (Nomenclature Committee) at its Tokyo meeting (1970).{{cite journal |last1=Wada|first1=Koji|last2=Yoshinaga|first2=Naganori|title=The structure of "Imogolite"|journal=The American Mineralogist|date=January–February 1969|volume=54|pages=50–71|url=http://www.minsocam.org/ammin/AM54/AM54_50.pdf|accessdate=13 March 2012}}{{Cite journal |title=Summary of national and international recommendations on clay mineral nomenclature: Clays and Clay Minerals|journal=Clays and Clay Minerals|year=1971|volume=19|page=131|doi=10.1346/ccmn.1971.0190210 | last1 = Bailey | first1 = S. W.}} Fleischer (1983) described it as a variety of [[allophane]] and it was finally redefined and approved by the IMA/CNMNC 1986.{{Cite book |last=Fleischer |first=M. |authorlink=Michael Fleischer (mineralogist) |year=1983 |title=Glossary of Mineral Species |publisher=Mineralogical Record |location=Tucson, AZ}}{{Cite journal |last=Bayliss |first=P. |title=Mineralogical notes: mineral nomenclature: imogolite |url=http://rruff.info/rruff_1.0/uploads/MM51_327.pdf |journal=Mineralogical Magazine |year=1987 |volume=51 |page=327 |doi=10.1180/minmag.1987.051.360.18}} *** Amorphous allophane, [[Inorganic nanotube|nanotube]]-like imogolite ({{Chem|Al|2|SiO|3|(OH)|4}}), [[halloysite]]-10Å ({{Chem|Al|2|Si|2|O|5|(OH)|4|·2H|2|O}}), halloysite-7Å ({{Chem|Al|2|Si|2|O|5|(OH)|4}}) and [[gibbsite]] ({{Chem|Al(OH)|3}}) are thought to be products of [[Tuff (rock)|tuff]] [[weathering]]. ** [[Betalommosovite]] was described by Gerasimovskiy and Kazakova (1962) and discredited by the IMA-CNMMN (IMA1967 s.p.). It was published without approval and listed as discredited on the 'IMA/CNMNC List of Mineral Names' (2009). Later, betalomonosovite was revalidated (IMA2014-J).[https://www.mindat.org/min-647.html Mindat]{{cite journal |authors=Sokolova, E., Hawthorne, F. C., Abdu, Y.A., Genovese, A. & Cámara, F. |year=2015 |title=Reapproval of betalomonosovite as a valid mineral species: single-crystal X-ray diffraction, HRTEM, Raman and IR |journal=Periodico di Mineralogia |volume=ECMS2015 |pages=157–158}} ** [[Jichengite]] as xinghuaite (IMA1984-047) was rejected by the IMA-CNMMN. Jichengite (IMA1994-039) was rejected by the IMA-CNMMN, as well. Unfortunately, it was published without approval in 2011.[https://www.mineralienatlas.de/lexikon/index.php/MineralData?mineral=Jichengite Mineralienatlas]{{cite journal |authors=Yu, Z., Hao, Z., Wang, H., Yin, S., Cai, J. |year=2011 |title=Jichengite 3CuIr2S4·(Ni,Fe)9S8, a New Mineral, and Its Crystal Structure |journal=Acta Geologica Sinica |volume=85 |pages=1022–1027 |doi=10.1111/j.1755-6724.2011.00537.x}} **UM1991-//-COF:BaCaCe (IMA1989-012), a calcium analogue of [[cordylite]]-(Ce) from Bayan Obo mine, had the approval procedure suspended by [[Joseph A. Mandarino]], because of the cerium dominant cordylite (IMA2000-C).[https://www.mindat.org/min-42618.html Mindat] *Other curiosities: **[[Niggliite]] (former 1.AG.60, year: 1938), [[sorosite]] (former 1.AC.15, IMA1994-047), [[yuanjiangite]] (former 1.AC.15, IMA1993-028) are not classified as tin alloys (PGE-metal alloys and indium-tin family) in ''Fleischer's Glossary''. But, they are stannide minerals (nickeline mineral group), sulfide mineral class there.{{Cite book |first1=Malcolm E. |last1=Back |title=Fleischer’s Glossary of Mineral Species |year=2014 |edition=11 |publisher=Mineralogical Record Inc. |pages=434 |location=Tucson AZ}}{{Cite book |first1=Malcolm E. |last1=Back |first2=Joseph A. |last2=Mandarino |title=Fleischer’s Glossary of Mineral Species |year=2008 |edition=10 |publisher=Mineralogical Record Inc. |pages=345 |location=Tucson AZ}} **[[Tiragalloite]] (9.BJ.25, IMA1969-061, Mn42+(HAsSi3O13)), is an arsenosilicate and [[grenmarite]] (9.BE.25, IMA2003-024, (Na,Ca)4(Mn,Na)(Zr,Mn)2(Zr,Ti)(Si2O7)2(O,F)4) is a zirconium silicate (analogous to the more common [[aluminosilicate]]s, borosilicates and titanium silicates).[http://www.mindat.org/min-3974.html MinDat - Tiragalloite][http://www.mindat.org/min-27516.html MinDat - Grenmarite] **Mostly anthropogenic minerals: [[abhurite]] (3.DA.30), [[lausenite]] (7.CB.70), [[guildite]] (7.DC.30), [[hoelite]] (10.CA.15), [[calclacite]] (10.AA.25). **[[Studtite]] (4.GA.15, year: 1947) is the first peroxide mineral, the [[facies]] radioactivity generate peroxide. **[[Ianthinite]] (4.GA.10, year: 1926), [[Uranium|U]](IV) is one of the constituents of the mineral), it gets a layer of [[schoepite]]/ [[metaschoepite]] in the presence of oxygen. **[[Polyoxometalate]]s: ***[[Menezesite]] (4.FN.05, IMA2005-023) and [[aspedamite]] (IMA2011-056), are the only natural heteropolyniobates known. ***[[Ophirite]] (IMA2013-017) is a mineral with a heteropolytungstate tri-lacunary [[Keggin structure|keggin anion]]. ***[[Melcherite]] (IMA2015-018) and [[peterandresenite]] (IMA2012-084) have a lindqvist anion. **Inosilicate, biopyriboles: ***[[Jimthompsonite]] (IMA1977-011) is a triple chain inosilicate. ***[[Chesterite]] (IMA1977-010) is a connected double chain inosilicate. **Inosilicate, double dreier chains: ***[[Xonotlite]] (Y: 1866) is an inosilicate with double dreier chains. ***[[Chivruaiite]] (IMA2004-052) is an inosilicate double dreier chains of (SiO4) tetrahedra. ***[[Zorite]] (IMA1972-011) is an inosilicate double dreier chains of (SiO4) tetrahedra. ***[[Haineaultite]] (IMA1997-015) is an inosilicate double dreier chains of (SiO4) tetrahedra. **Other inosilicates: ***[[Veblenite]] (IMA2010-050) has a veblenite ribbon (Si8O22). ***[[Yangite]] (IMA2012-052) is an inosilicate with two-connected double chain. ***[[Yegorovite]] (IMA2008-033) is an inosilicate with single zig-zag chains of Si tetrahedra. **[[Icosahedrite]] (IMA2010-042), the only natural quasicrystal known. **[[Comancheite]] (IMA2013-B/ IMA1980-077, former 3.DD.65) is a mercury nitride mineral now. **α-[[Sulfur]] (old); chemical formula unit with 1 atom; unit cell with 128 formula units (Z). **[[Whitecapsite]] (IMA2012-030), chemical formula: H16Fe2+5Fe3+14Sb3+6(AsO4)18O16·120H2O; unit cell with 1 formula unit (Z). **[[Megacyclite]] (9.CP.10, IMA1991-015); chemical formula unit with 111 atoms; unit cell with 4 formula units (Z). **[[Labyrinthite]] (9.CO.10, IMA2002-065); chemical formula unit with 278.5 atoms; unit cell with 3 formula units (Z). **[[Ashcroftine-(Y)]] (9.DN.15, year: 1933); chemical formula unit with 180 atoms; unit cell with 4 formula units (Z). == Notes == [[File:Feldspar group.svg|thumb|[[Feldspar]] series]] {{al2sio5 phase diagram}} * Attention with the [[amphiboles]]: some mineral names have been redefined (IMA2012 s.p. was the last revision), some even more than once; i.e. their chemical formula range changed.{{Cite journal|authors=Frank C. Hawthorne, Roberta Oberti, George E. Harlow, Walter V. Maresch, Robert F. Martin, John C. Schumacher, Mark D. Welch |title=Nomenclature of the amphibole supergroup |journal=American Mineralogist |year=2012 |volume=97 |pages=2031–2048 |doi=10.2138/am.2012.4276}} For example, aluminotaramite ('IMA2006-023', 9.DE.20) is a synonym of [[ferro-taramite]], sodic-ferri-ferropedrizite (IMA2003 s.p., 9.DE.25) was renamed to [[ferro-ferri-pedrizite]], ehimeite is a synonym of [[chromio-pargasite]] ('IMA2011-023', 9.DE.15), kôzulite is a synonym of [[mangano-arfvedsonite]] ('IMA1968-028', 9.DE.25) and kornite is a synonym of [[potassic-mangani-leakeite]] ('IMA1992-032', 9.DE.25). *Some IMA-CNMNC approved minerals have a questionable status on mineralienatlas.de, but their unit cell parameters are given on mindat.org (or vice versa). Their status here doesn't change, it remains 'approved mineral'. *The mineral systematic given on Nickel-Strunz (9 and 10 ed) is not controversial. [[Dmisteinbergite]] ([[feldspar]], 9.EG.15), uranyl sorovanadates (4.HD. ids) and silica family (4.DA. ids) are some exceptions, for instance. * Great care must be taken with definitions and their redefinitions. There is a difference between rocks, natural minerals and chemical compounds. Some examples: rocksalt (a redirect), [[halite]] and sodium chloride; kaolin earth (a redirect) and [[kaolinite]]; apatite, strict sense ([[chlorapatite]], [[fluorapatite]] and [[hydroxylapatite]]), apatite group and apatite supergroup; kaolinite-serpentine group (alias serpentine), [[serpentine subgroup]], serpentinization and [[serpentinite]]; olivine structural group (after rruff.nfo/ima); olivine group and [[olivine]] (a [[fosterite]] var.); [[spessartine]] (a [[garnet]]) and spessartite (a [[lamprophyre]]); [[iron]] (element), [[telluric iron]] (alias native iron) and [[meteoric iron]]; [[phyllosilicate minerals]] (alias sheet silicates) and [[clay]]s; [[pyrochlore]] (invalid mineral name since 2010), pyrochlore group and pyrochlore supergroup; [[antimony]] and [[stibnite]] (alias antimonite); etc. * The data of a mineral on the databases is similar but not equal. For instance: ** [[Opal]] is a valid IMA/CNMNC name but it is a mineraloid (a mixture of [[cristobalite]] and/or [[tridymite]] and amorphous silica), it has a page on Mindat.org and Webmineral.com but not on the Handbook of Mineralogy. *** Ice, [[Mercury (element)|mercury]] (low melting point); allophane, [[delvauxite]], [[hisingerite]] (amorphous/ poorly cristalline); [[actinolite]], [[augite]], [[omphacite]], [[sanidine]] (intermediate member of a [[solid solution]] series) are IMA/CNMNC valid names too. The reasons can be inherited pre-IMA status, practical reasons or entrenchment in the literature, including medical and legal usage. ** [[Oligoclase]]I is an albite variety on Mindat.org and it has pages on the Handbook of Minerals and Webmineral.com, see 'List of minerals (synonyms)' ([[plagioclase]]/[[albite]]-[[anorthite]] series). It is not the only intermediate member of a solid solution series with a page on the Handbook of Mineralogy ([[List of minerals (synonyms)#Mineral varieties|mineral varieties]]). ** The Handbook of Mineralogy has pages on [[clinochrysotile]], [[orthochrysotile]] and [[parachrysotile]], but not on [[chrysotile]]; but they are polytypes of chrysotile, see 'List of minerals (synonyms)'. ** Mindat.org uses to give the chemical formula of some minerals as a range (between parentheses, if tin dominant then [[herzenbergite]]: (Sn,Pb)SnS2; otherwise [[teallite]]: (Pb,Sn)SnS2), on the other side the IMA Database of Mineral Properties/ Rruff Project uses to give the ideal chemical formula of the solid solution end member (herzenbergite: SnS). ***The given chemical names are a compromise for information purposes, being based on the Nickel-Strunz code too. Most of the time the chemical formula on rruff.info was used, sometimes the simpler one on mindat.org. To illustrate it: [[bartonite]], K3Fe10S14 (mindat.org), K6Fe20S26S (rruff.info); [[bayleyite]], Mg2(UO2)(CO3)3·18H2O (mindat.org), Mg2(UO2)(CO3)3(H2O)12·6H2O (rruff.info) and [[bredigite]], Ca7Mg(SiO4)4 (mindat.org), CaCa13Mg2(SiO4)8 (rruff.info). ***Caution with the chemical formula units of silicates and their "formula masses". Some molecules have a repeating unit, these might be chains, networks, [[polymers]], and so the true molecule might be a multiple of the smallest repeating unit (the [[unit cell]] of a crystal is formed by repeating 'Z' times the chemical formula). Examples: [[wadsleyite]] (Mg2SiO4) a sorosilicate and high pressure polymorth of [[forsterite]] and [[ringwoodite]]; [[leucophanite]] (NaCaBeSi2O6F), but it has Nickel-Strunz identifier 9.DH.05 (inosilicates with 4-periodic single chains, Si4O12); [[clinoenstatite]] (MgSiO3), but it has Nickel-Strunz identifier 9.DA.10 (inosilicates with 2-periodic single chains, Si2O6); [[scolecite]] (CaAl2Si3O10·3H2O), but it has Nickel-Strunz identifier 9.GA.05 (zeolites with T5O10 units – the fibrous zeolites); [[mogánite]] (SiO2), but it has Nickel-Strunz identifier 4.DA.20 (oxides with small cations: silica family). *The existence in nature of some questionable/ doubtful minerals is very unlikely at all or at the [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]]. For example, [[magnesium chloride|chloromagnesite]]Q (Y: 1872, MgCl2) 3.AB.20 and [[zinc sulfate|zinkosite]]Q (Y: 1852, ZnSO4) 7.AB.10.[http://www.mindat.org/min-1022.html Mindat.org - Chloromagnesite][http://www.mindat.org/min-4418.html Mindat.org - Zinkosite] *Some names are not names of minerals anymore, but names of a group of minerals: **Micas, [[biotite]] group.[http://www.mindat.org/min-677.html Mindat.org - Biotite]No Webmineral reference[http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/biotite.pdf Handbookofmineralogy - Biotite] ***The IMA/CNMMN, Subcommittee on Nomenclature of the Micas (1998, 1999) has recommended that the name biotite be used for a series including [[phlogopite]], [[siderophyllite]], [[annite]] and [[eastonite]].{{Cite journal |author=Rieder, Milan, Cavazzini, Giancarlo, D'yakonov, Yurii S., Frank-Kamenetskii, Viktor A. |journal=Canadian Mineralogist |year=1998 |title=Nomenclature of the micas (IMA/CNMMN Mica Group Subcommittee Report) |volume=36 |pages=905–912 |url=http://www.minsocam.org/MSA/IMA/ima98(10).pdf }} **Zeolites: [[chabazite]] group,;[http://www.mindat.org/min-956.html Mindat.org - Chabazite]No Webmineral reference[http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/chabazite.pdf Handbookofmineralogy - Chabazite] [[dachiardite]] group,;[http://www.mindat.org/min-1212.html Mindat.org - Dachiardite][http://www.webmineral.com/data/Dachiardite.shtml Webmineral - Dachiardite]No Handbook of Mineralogy reference [[heulandite]] group.[http://www.mindat.org/min-1889.html Mindat.org - Heulandite]No Webmineral reference[http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/heulandite.pdf Handbookofmineralogy - Heulandite] ** [[List of minerals (synonyms)#Pyrochlore supergroup|Pyrochlore supergroup]]: *** The pyrochlore supergroup was revised in 2010. The update of the databases isn't complete, yet. ***Groups: [[pyrochlore]],;[http://www.mindat.org/min-3316.html Mindat.org - Pyrochlore][http://www.webmineral.com/data/Pyrochlore.shtml Webmineral - Pyrochlore][http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/pyrochlore.pdf Handbookofmineralogy - Pyrochlore] [[Romeite|roméite]],;[http://www.mindat.org/min-3443.html Mindat.org - Roméite][http://www.webmineral.com/data/Rom%E9ite.shtml Webmineral - Roméite][http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/romeite.pdf Handbookofmineralogy - Roméite] [[betafite]],;[http://www.mindat.org/min-649.html Mindat.org - Betafite][http://www.webmineral.com/data/Betafite.shtml Webmineral - Betafite][http://www.handbookofmineralogy.com/pdfs/betafite.pdf Handbookofmineraology - Betafite] [[microlite]],;[http://www.mindat.org/min-2705.html Mindat.org - Microlite group] [[elsmoreite]].[http://www.mindat.org/min-40371.html Mindat.org - Elsmoreite group] == Nomenclature dictionary == ;Special minerals (relaxed sense) *Native elements (class 1): carbides, silicides, nitrides, phosphides, elements, alloys, amalgams *Special minerals (strict sense): tellurium(VI) oxysalts ([Te6+Ox], trioxotellurate(IV) tetraoxotellurate(VI) [Te4+O3][Te6+O4]) ;"Ore" minerals (sulfides and oxides) *Sulfide class (class 2): sulfides [S], selenides [Se], tellurides [Te], arsenides [As], antimonides [Sb], bismuthides [Bi], sulfantimonides [SbxSy], sulfarsenides [AsxSy], sulfbismuthides [BixSy], sulfastannides [SnxSy], plumboarsenide [As,Pb], plumbobismuthide [Bi,Pb] *Oxide class (class 4): sulfites(IV) [SO3]2−, selenites(IV) [SeO3]2−, iodates [IO3], trioxotellurate(IV) [Te4+O3]2−, dihydroxotellurate(IV) [Te4+O(OH)2], pentaoxoditellurate(IV) [(Te4+)2O5]2−, vanadyl anion [V4+O2]2- ;Evaporite and similar minerals *Halide class (class 3): fluoride [F], chloride [Cl], bromide [Br], iodide [I], tetrafluoroborates [BF4], hexafluorosilicates [SiF6], hexachlorothallate(III) [Tl3+Cl6] *Carbonate and nitrate class (class 5): carbonates [CO3], bicarbonate [HCO3] **Nitrates (subclass 5.N): nitrates [NO3] *Borate class (class 6): metaborates [B2O4], trioxoborate [BO3], tetrahydroborate [B(OH)4] ;Mineral structures with a tetrahedral unit, monomeric minerals *Sulfate class (class 7), monomeric minerals: sulfates [SO4]2−, tungstates [WO4]2−, niobates [NbO4]2−, molybdates [MoO4]2−, chromates [CrO4]2−, tetraoxotantalate [TaO4], thiosulphates [SO3S]2− *Phosphate class (class 8), monomeric minerals: phosphates(V) [PO4]3−, arsenates(V) [AsO4]3−, vanadates(V) [VO4]3−, hydroxophosphates(V) [PO3OH]2−, dihydroxophosphates(V) [PO2(OH)2], hydroxoarsenates(V) [AsO3OH]2−, dihydroxoarsenates(V) [AsO2(OH)2] *Nesosilicates (subclass 9.A), monomeric minerals: tetraoxosilicate [SiO4], hydrotrioxosilicate [SiO3OH] ;Mineral structures with a tetrahedral unit, di- and chain silicates *Sorosilicates (subclass 9.B): heptaoxodisilicate [Si2O7], hydrohexaoxodisilicate [Si2O6OH], tetraoxosilicate heptaoxodisilicate [SiO4][Si2O7], decaoxotrisilicate [Si3O10], undecaoxotetrasilicate [Si4O11] *Inosilicates (subclass 9.D): **Single-chain inosilicates: pyroxenes **Double-chain inosilicates: amphiboles **Other inosilicates: ;Mineral structures with a tetrahedral unit, framework silicates *Cyclosilicates (subclass 9.C): *Phyllosilicates (subclass 9.E): *Tridimensional silicate frameworks: tectosilicates (subclass 9.F) **Silica family (class 4, family DA): dioxosilicate [SiO2] *Tectosilicates, zeolites (subclass 9.G): ;Mineral structures with a tetrahedral unit, other cases *Dimeric and polymeric minerals, phosphate and sulfate class: polyphosphates, polyoxometalates, hexaniobates [Nb6O19], pyrophosphates [P2O7], pyroarsenates [As2O7], decavanadates [V10O28] ;Other cases (relaxed sense) *Organic minerals, salts of organic acids (class 10, division A): oxalates, citrates, acetates, formiate *Cations: divalent [dimercury] [Hg2]2+, uranyl [U6+O2]2+, ammonium [NH4]+, tetramethylammonium [N(CH3)4]+ *Other building blocks: stannide alloys [Sn], aluminide alloys [Al], aluminosilicates, borosilicates, aluminoborosilicates, paddlewheel cluster [e.g.: uranyl-tricarbonate cluster (UO2)(CO3)3] == Gallery == File:H2O-NaCl-phase-diagram-greek.svg|[[Halite]]/ hydrohalite [[phase diagram]] File:An-Wo-Sp-phase-diagram-greek.svg|Ternary phase diagram: [[anorthite]] (CaAl2Si2O8), [[wollastonite]] (CaSiO3) and [[titanite]] (CaTiSiO5) File:Sulfur phase diagram.svg|[[Sulfur]]/ β-sulfur diagram, rosickyite turns slowly to α-sulfur at room temperature File:Carbon basic phase diagram.png|Theoretically predicted phase diagram of carbon File:Biotit Mischkristallreihe.jpg|[[Biotite]] series ([[micas]]) == See also == {{Portal|Earth sciences}} {{Wikipedia books|Mineralogy}} * [[Classification of minerals - Non silicates]] * [[Classification of minerals - Silicates]] * [[Geology]] * [[List of critical mineral raw materials]] * [[List of rock types]] * [[Mineralogy]] * [[Mineraloid]] * [[rock (geology)|Rock]] == Further reading == *{{Cite book |last=Clark |first=A. |year=1993 |edition=3 |publisher=Chapman & Hall |location=London |pages=852 |title=Hey's Mineral Index}} *{{Cite book |author1=Gaines, R.V. |author2=Skinner, H.C. |author3=Foord, E.E. |author4=Mason, B. |author5=Rosenzweig, A. |year=1997 |title=Dana’s New Mineralogy: The System of Mineralogy of James Dwight Dana and Edward Salisbury |edition=8 |publisher= Wiley & Sons |place=New York |pages=1819 |isbn=978-0-471-19310-4 }} *{{Cite book |last=de Fourestier |first=Jeffrey |year=1999 |edition=2 |title=Glossary of Mineral Synonyms. Canadian Mineralogist Special Publication 2 |publisher=Mineralogical Association of Canada |place=Ottawa |pages=445 |isbn=0921294441 }} *{{Cite book |last=Strunz |first=Hugo |last2=Nickel |first2=Ernest H. |authorlink=Karl Hugo Strunz |year=2001 |edition=9 |title=Strunz Mineralogical Tables |publisher=Schweizerbart |place=Stuttgart |pages=869 |isbn=978-3-510-65188-7 }} *{{Cite book |last=Ferraiolo |first=J.A. |year=2003 |title=A Systematic Classification of Minerals |place=Bowie, US-MD |pages=441 }} *{{Cite book |first1=Malcolm E. |last1=Back |title=Fleischer’s Glossary of Mineral Species |year=2014 |edition=11 |publisher=Mineralogical Record Inc. |pages=434 |location=Tucson AZ}} *{{Cite book |last1=Deer |first1=William A. |authorlink1=William Alexander Deer |last2=Howie |first2=Robert A. |authorlink2=Robert A. Howie |last3=Zussman |first3=Jack |title=An Introduction to the Rock-Forming Minerals |publisher=Mineralogical Society |location=London |isbn=9780903056274 |edition=3 |year=2013 |pages=498 }} Note: known as [[An Introduction to the Rock-Forming Minerals|DHZ]]. == Notes == === References === {{Reflist|2}} {{Refbegin}} *Web: rruff.info/ima/, 'IMA database of mineral properties' switchboard: **'Not an IMA approved mineral' tag – E.g. [[buserite]] **'Discredited' mineral tag – E.g. bindheimite **'Pending publication' tag – E.g. [[drobecite]] (IMA 2002-034) **'Questionable mineral species' tag – E.g. [[shubnikovite]] {{Refend}} == External links == {{Commons category|Minerals}} *[http://www.mindat.org/index.php Mindat.org], the mineral database *[http://webmineral.com/Alphabetical_Listing.shtml Webmineral.com] *[http://www.mineralatlas.eu/ Mineralatlas.eu] {{Strunz}} [[Category:Minerals| List02]] [[Category:Mineralogy|*List02]] [[Category:Geology-related lists|Minerals02]]

page.title: List of mountains of the Balkans

revision.text:
This is a list of [[mountain]]s of the [[Balkan Mountains|Balkans]].
==By alphabet== * [[Mount Ainos|Ainos]] (1,628 m), [[Greece]] * [[Bjelašnica]] (2,067 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Baba Mountain, Macedonia|Baba]] (Pelister, 2,601 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Balkan Mountains]] (Botev, 2,376 m), [[Bulgaria]], [[Serbia]] * [[Besna Kobila]] (1,923m), [[Serbia]] * [[Belasica]] (Radomir, 2,029 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]], [[Bulgaria]] and [[Greece]] * [[Bistra Mountain|Bistra]] (Medenica, 2,163 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Bjeshket e Nemuna]] (2,694m), [[Dinaric Alps|Kosovo]], [[Albania]], [[Montenegro]] * [[Biokovo]] (1,762 m), [[Croatia]] * [[Celoica]] (Dobra Voda, 2,062 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Cvrsnica|Čvrsnica]] (2,238 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Deshat]] (Velivar, 2,375 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] * [[Dinara]] (Troglav peak 1,913 m; Dinara peak 1,831 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Croatia]]-[[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Galičica]] (Magaro, 2,254 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] * [[Hymettus]] (1,026 m), east of [[Athens]], [[Greece]] * [[Igman]] (1,502 m), [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Jakupica]] (Solunska Glava, 2,540 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Jablanica Mountain|Jablanica]] (Black Stone, 2,257 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] * [[Kopaonik]] (Pančićev vrh 2,017 m), [[Serbia]] * [[Kožuf|Kožuf/Tzena]] (Zelenbeg, 2,171 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Greece]] * [[Mount Korab|Korab]] (Golem Korab/Maja e Korabit peak, 2,764 m), highest point in [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] * [[Korab II]] (2,756m), [[Albania]] & [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Maglić (mountain)|Maglić]] (2,386 m), [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Mount Parnassus|Parnassus]] (2,460 m), [[Greece]] * [[Mount Olympus (Mountain)|Olympus]] ([[Mytikas]] peak 2,918 m), highest mountain in [[Greece]] - legendary home of the [[Greece|Greek]] gods * [[Orjen]] (1,894 m), highest mountain in littoral [[Montenegro]], during glacial periods the most heavily glaciated Mediterranean mountain * [[Osogovo]] (Ruen, 2,251 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Bulgaria]] * [[Panachaicus]] (1,926 m), northernmost mountain of the [[Peloponnese]], east of [[Patras]], [[Greece]] * [[Pindos]] ([[Smolikas]] peak 2,637 m), second highest mountain in [[Greece]] * [[Pirin]] (Vihren, 2,915 m), [[Bulgaria]], third highest mountain in the Balkans, after Musala in Bulgaria and Mount Olympus in Greece * [[Prenj]] (Zelena Glava, 2,155 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Prenj]] (Lupoglav, 2,102 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Rhodope Mountains|Rhodopes]] (Golyam Perelik, 2,191 m), [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]] * [[Rila]] (Musala, 2,925 m), [[Bulgaria]], highest mountain in Bulgaria and the Balkans * [[Sakar Mountain|Sakar]] (Vishegrad, 895 m), [[Bulgaria]] * [[Stogovo]] (Golem Rid, 2,278 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Sharr mountain]] (2,747 m), [[Kosovo]] and [[Albania]] and [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Triglav]] (2,864 m), [[Slovenia]] * [[Vitosha]] (Cherni vrah, 2,290 m) [[Bulgaria]] * [[Voras Mountains|Voras/Nidže]] (2,521 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Greece]] * [[Vranica]] (2,110 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Zlatibor]] (Tornik 1,496 m; Čigota 1,422 m), [[Serbia]]
==By height==
* [[Rila]] ([[Musala]], 2,925 m), [[Bulgaria]], highest mountain in Bulgaria and the Balkans * [[Mount Olympus (Mountain)|Olympus]] ([[Mytikas]] peak 2,918 m), highest mountain in [[Greece]] - legendary home of the [[Greece|Greek]] gods * [[Pirin]] (Vihren, 2,915 m), [[Bulgaria]], third highest mountain in the Balkans, after Musala in Bulgaria and Mount Olympus in Greece * [[Triglav]] (Triglav, 2,864 m), [[Slovenia]] * [[Mount Korab|Korab]] (Golem Korab/Maja e Korabit peak, 2,764 m), highest point in [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] * [[Korab II]] (2,756m), [[Albania]] & Macedonia|Baba]] (Pelister, 2,601 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Jakupica]] (Solunska Glava, 2,540 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Voras Mountains|Voras/Nidže]] (2,521 m), [[Republic of [[Bulgaria]], [[Serbia]] * [[Deshat]] (Velivar, 2,375 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Albania]] * [[Vitosha]] (Cherni vrah, 2,290 m) [[Bulgaria]] * [[Stogovo]] (Golem Rid, 2,278 m), [[Republic of (Golyam Perelik, 2,191 m), [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]] * [[Kožuf|Kožuf/Tzena]] (Zelenbeg, 2,171 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] and [[Greece]] * [[Bistra Mountain|Bistra]] (Medenica, 2,163 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Prenj]] (Zelena Glava, 2,155 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Prenj]] (Lupoglav, 2,102 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Bjelašnica]] (2,067 m), [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Celoica]] (Dobra Voda, 2,062 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Belasica]] (Radomir, 2,029 m), [[Republic of Macedonia]], [[Bulgaria]] and [[Greece]] * [[Kopaonik]] (Pančićev vrh 2,017 m), [[Serbia]] * [[Panachaicus]] (1,926 m), northernmost mountain of the [[Peloponnese]], east of [[Patras]], [[Greece]] * [[Besna Kobila]] (1,923m), [[Serbia]] * [[Dinara]] (Troglav peak 1,913 m; Dinara peak 1,831 m), [[Dinaric Alps|Dinarides]], [[Croatia]]-[[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Orjen]] (1,894 m), highest mountain in littoral [[Montenegro]], during glacial periods the most heavily glaciated Mediterranean mountain * [[Mount Ainos|Ainos]] (1,628 m), [[Greece]] * [[Igman]] (1,502 m), [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Zlatibor]] (Tornik 1,496 m; Čigota 1,422 m), [[Serbia]] * [[Parnitha]] (1,413 m), [[Athens]], [[Greece]] * [[Penteli]] (1,109 m), [[Athens]], [[Greece]] * [[Hymettus]] (1,026 m), east of [[Athens]], [[Greece]] * [[Sakar Mountain|Sakar]] (Vishegrad, 895 m), [[Bulgaria]]

page.title: List of political and geographic subdivisions by total area from 5,000 to 7,000 square kilometers
List of predecessors of sovereign states in Europe

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=April 2011}}{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Multiple issues| {{expert needed|date=July 2010}} {{refimprove|date=July 2010}} }} This is a '''list of all present [[sovereign state]]s in [[Europe]] and their predecessors'''. The borders of Europe are difficult to define. The borders between Europe and [[Asia]] are generally agreed to be the [[Caucasus Mountains]], the [[Ural Mountains]], the [[Bosphorus]] and the [[Dardanelles]]. {| class="wikitable" ! Sovereign state ! Predecessors |- | [[Albania]] | [[Principality of Arbanon]] (1190–1255) :::{{flag|Byzantine Empire}} (1190–1204) :::{{noflag|[[Despotate of Epirus]]}} (1205–1255)
