revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A U-shaped valley originally cut by water under the glacial ice near the margin of continental ice sheets" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A U-shaped valley originally cut by water under the glacial ice near the margin of continental ice sheets}} [[File:New York's Finger Lakes.jpg|thumb|280px|right|[[New York (state)|New York]]'s [[Finger Lakes]]. Lying south of Lake Ontario, the Finger Lakes formed in tunnel valleys.]] A '''tunnel valley''' is a large, long, [[U-shaped valley]] originally cut under the [[glacial ice]] near the margin of continental ice sheets such as that now covering Antarctica and formerly covering portions of all continents during past [[ice ages|glacial ages]].<ref name=J>{{Cite journal | last = Jørgensen | first =Flemming | authorlink = |author2=Peter B.E. Sandersen | title = Buried and open tunnel valleys in Denmark—erosion beneath multiple ice sheets | journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 25 | issue = 11–12 | pages = 1339–1363 | publisher = | location = | date = June 2006 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.quascirev.2005.11.006 | id = |bibcode = 2006QSRv...25.1339J }}</ref>
A tunnel valley can be as long as {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}}, {{convert|4|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide, and {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep (its depth may vary along its length).
Tunnel valleys were formed by subglacial erosion by water and served as subglacial drainage pathways carrying large volumes of melt water. Their cross-sections exhibit steep-sided flanks similar to [[fjord]] walls, and their flat bottoms are typical of subglacial glacial erosion.
They presently appear as dry valleys, lakes, seabed depressions, and as areas filled with sediment. If they are filled with sediment, their lower layers are filled primarily with glacial, [[glacio-fluvial|glaciofluvial]] or [[glaciolacustrine deposits|glaciolacustrine]] sediment, supplemented by upper layers of temperate infill.<ref name=Stucki2010>{{Cite journal | last = Durst Stucki | first =Mirjam | authorlink = | author2 = Regina Reber and Fritz Schlunegger | title = Subglacial tunnel valleys in the Alpine foreland: an example from Bern, Switzerland | journal = Swiss Journal of Geosciences | volume = 103| issue = 3| pages = 363–374| publisher = Springer (Online First) | location = | date = June 2010 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1007/s00015-010-0042-0 | id = }}</ref> They can be found in areas formerly covered by glacial ice sheets including Africa, Asia, North America, Europe, Australia and offshore in the North Sea, the Atlantic and in waters near Antarctica.
Tunnel valleys appear in the technical literature under several terms, including tunnel channels, subglacial valleys, [[iceway]]s, [[Snake coils (geology)|snake coils]] and linear incisions.
==Significance== Understanding tunnel valleys is important because: * They serve as a marker for areas with the potential for effective oil exploration in Africa * Their bedrock boundaries and glacial infill makes them effective aquifers in many regions * Soil engineers must accommodate the variations which they exhibit when boring tunnels and establishing foundations * They provide one of several signatures marking the edge of former glaciations
Tunnel valleys play a useful role in identifying oil rich areas in [[Arabia]] and [[North Africa]]. The Upper [[Ordovician]]–Lower [[Silurian]] materials there contain a roughly {{convert|20|m|ft|abbr=on}} thick, carbon-rich layer of black shale. Approximately 30% of the world's oil is found in these shale deposits. Although the origin of these deposits is still under study, it has been established that the shale routinely overlies glacial and glacio-marine sediment deposited ~445 million years before the present by the [[Hirnantian|Hirnantian glaciation]]. The shale has been linked to glacial meltwater nutrient enrichment of the shallow marine environment. Hence the presence of tunnel valleys is an indicator of the presence of oil in these areas.<ref name=Armstrong2009>{{Cite journal | last = Armstrong| first =Howard A. | authorlink = | author2 = Geoffrey D. Abbottb, Brian R. Turnera, Issa M. Makhloufc, Aminu Bayawa Muhammadb, Nikolai Pedentchoukd and Henning Peterse| title = Black shale deposition in an Upper Ordovician–Silurian permanently stratified, peri-glacial basin, southern Jordan | journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology| volume = 273| issue = = 3–4 | pages = 368–377 | publisher = Copyright © 2008 Elsevier B.V. | location = | date = 15 March 2009| url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.palaeo.2008.05.005 | id = }}</ref>
Tunnel valleys represent a substantial fraction of all melt-water drainage from glaciers. Melt-water drainage influences the flow of glacial ice, which is important in understanding of the duration of glacial–interglacial periods and aids in identifying glacial cyclicity, a problem that is important to palaeoenvironmental investigations.<ref name=Smellie2008A>{{Cite journal | last = Smellie | first = John L. | authorlink = | author2 = J.S. Johnson, W.C. McIntosh, R. Esser, M.T. Gudmundsson, M.J. Hambrey, B. van Wyk de Vries | title = Six million years of glacial history recorded in volcanic lithofacies of the James Ross Island Volcanic Group, Antarctic Peninsula | journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology | volume = 260 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 122–148 | publisher = | location = | date = 7 April 2008 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.palaeo.2007.08.011 | id = }}</ref>
Tunnel valleys are typically eroded into bedrock and filled with glacial debris of varying sizes. This configuration makes them excellent at capturing and storing water. Hence they serve an important role as [[aquifer]]s across much of [[Northern Europe]], [[Canada]] and the [[United States]]. Examples include [[Oak Ridges Moraine| Oak Ridges Moraine Aquifer]], Spokane Valley-Rathdrum Prairie Aquifer, [[Mahomet Aquifer]], the [http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2009AM/finalprogram/abstract_164191.htm Saginaw Lobe Aquifer], and the [http://pubs.usgs.gov/ha/ha730/ch_m/M-text1.html Corning Aquifer].
==Characteristics== [[File:Tunneldal Noordbergum.jpg|280px|left|thumb|A figure in Dutch showing the cross-section of a tunnel valley which has been refilled after erosion into bedrock.]]
===Buried, open and partially filled=== Tunnel valleys have been observed as open valleys and as partially or totally buried valleys. If buried they may be partially or totally filled with glacial outwash or other debris. The valleys may be incised in bedrock, sand, silt, or clay.<ref name=J/>
A part of a tunnel valley may go uphill: water can flow uphill if it is under pressure in an enclosed pipe: for example in [[Doggerland]] (submerged land which is now part of the bed of the [[North Sea]]) are some infilled tunnel valleys that flowed from north to south across the hollow of the [[Outer Silver Pit]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=SrsrE8oZx44C&oi=fnd&pg=PR11&dq=Doggerland&ots=YzrIXDuQeI&sig=DaeFOytqn6t-JpW1-zBTGqVqO50#v=onepage&q=&f=false Vincent Gaffney, Kenneth Thomson, Simon Finch, Mapping Doggerland: The Mesolithic Landscapes of the Southern North Sea, University of Birmingham, 2007]</ref>
===Dimensions=== They vary in channel depth and width; Danish examples run from {{convert|0.5|-|4|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide and from {{convert|50|–|350|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep. They vary in depth/altitude along their course, exhibiting [[overdeepening]]; overdeepened sections cut into bedrock and typically are significantly deeper than either upstream or downstream sections of the same tunnel valley. They have steep sides which are frequently [[asymmetric valley|asymmetric]].<ref name=J/>
Tunnel valleys frequently include relatively straight individual segments parallel to and independent of one another. Tunnel valley courses may be periodically interrupted; the interruption may include a stretch of elevated [[esker]], indicating the channel ran through ice for a distance. The below-grade sections typically run {{convert|5|-|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} in length; in some cases the sections form a larger pattern of an interrupted channel composed of strings of depressions which can extend from {{convert|70|-|100|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=J/>
===Structure=== The upstream portion – that section furthest into the glacier – consists of a branching system forming a network, similar to the [[Anastomosis|anastomostic]] branching patterns of the upper reaches of a river (as contrasted with [[wikt:dendritic|dendritic]] patterns). They typically exhibit the largest cross-sectional area in the center of the course and terminate over a relatively short distance in elevated outwash fans at the ice-margin.<ref name=J/>
Tunnel valleys are found to cross the regional gradient – as a result they may be crosscut by modern stream networks. In one example, tributaries of the Kalamazoo River cut at nearly right angles across buried tunnel channel filled with ice and debris.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Kozlowski | first = Andrew L. | authorlink = | author2 = Alan E. Kehew and Brian C. Bird | title = Outburst flood origin of the Central Kalamazoo River Valley, Michigan, USA | journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 24 | issue = 22 | pages = 2354–2374 | publisher = Published by Elsevier Ltd. | location = | date = November 2005 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.quascirev.2005.03.016 | id = |bibcode = 2005QSRv...24.2354K | last3 = Bird | first3 = Brian C. }}</ref> They frequently terminate at a [[recessional moraine]]. Tunnel valleys from successive glaciations may crosscut one another.<ref>“Principles of glacier mechanics”; Roger LeB. Hooke; 2nd Edition; 2005; Cambridge</ref>
Tunnel valleys frequently run along roughly parallel courses. They originate in and run through regions which include clear evidence of glacial erosion through [[Abrasion (geology)|abrasion]] and may exhibit [[Glacial striation|striations]] and [[roche moutonnée]]. Depositional forms such as [[Moraine|terminal moraines]] and [[outwash fan]]s are found at their terminal end.<ref name=J/> In Michigan tunnel valley channels have been observed to diverge slightly with an average spacing between the channels of {{convert|6|km|mi|abbr=on}} and a [[standard deviation]] of {{convert|2.7|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Fisher2005>{{Cite journal | last = Fisher | first = Timothy G. | authorlink = | author2 = Harry M. Jol and Amber M. Boudreau | title = Saginaw Lobe tunnel channels (Laurentide Ice Sheet) and their significance in south-central Michigan, U.S | journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 24 | issue = 22 | pages = 2375–2391 | publisher = | location = | date = November 2005 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.quascirev.2004.11.019 | id = |bibcode = 2005QSRv...24.2375F | last3 = Boudreau | first3 = Amber M. }}</ref> [[File:Kawartha Lakes w legend.png|thumb|280px|right|The Kawartha lakes in Ontario formed in residual tunnel valleys from the [[Wisconsin glaciation|Late Wisconsonian]] glacial period. The water flow was from upper right to lower left. Close examination shows the existence of buried tunnel valleys as well – they can be identified by contrasting vegetation.]]
Tunnel valley channels often start or stop abruptly. They have convex-up longitudinal profiles. They are often occupied by elongated lakes of [[underfit]] streams. They frequently show signs of subsequent depositions such as eskers.<ref name=Fisher2005/>
===Evidence of erosion mechanisms=== Evidence suggests that erosion in a tunnel valley is primarily the result of water flow. They erode by meltwater, which it has been argued, episodically drains in repeated [[jökulhlaup]]s from subglacially stored lakes and reservoirs; examples of such motion have been observed in [[Antarctica]]. Although there is evidence of ice erosion such as linear striations in the bedrock, these are observed only in the widest valleys, and are believed to have played a secondary role.<ref name=J/>
The subglacial layout of valley tunnels/channels is predominantly oriented parallel to glacial ice flow lines – essentially they stretch from areas of thicker sheet ice toward areas of thinner sheet ice. They can exhibit reverse gradients, which result when pressurized meltwater flows over obstacles such as ridges or hills along the glacier bed.<ref name=Shaw2008/>
Tunnel valleys can be formed under extremely thick glacial ice – examples have been observed on the bottom of [[Lake Superior]] and in the oceans offshore in Antarctica. The course of a tunnel valley typically runs from thickest glacial ice to the glacier margin; as a result the glacial ice pressurizes the water such that it runs uphill toward its end.<ref name=J/>
==Formation of tunnel valleys/channels== Although there is agreement on the role of meltwater in creation of tunnel valleys, several theories are still under consideration for the role of that meltwater: :*Steady state theory – Boulton and Hindmarsh propose a steady state theory. They suggest tunnel valleys form in unconsolidated sediment when meltwater flows under pressure through an initially narrow subglacial conduit. With progressive removal of sediment by meltwater, ice deforms under its own weight into the cavity to create a tunnel valley through a positive feedback mechanism.<ref name=Boulton1987>{{Cite journal | last = Boulton | first = G.A.|author2=R.C.A. Hindmarsh | title = Sediment deformation beneath glaciers; rheology and geological consequences | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research | volume = 92 | issue = B2 | pages = 9059–9082 | publisher = American Geophysical Union| location = | date = 27 January 1987 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1029/JB092iB09p09059| id = | bibcode=1987JGR....92.9059B}}</ref> :*Jökulhlaup driven erosion – Piotrowski argues that ice sheets may, in some instances, be cold-based; that is they contact land that is frozen (permafrost) and they freeze to the permafrost. Meltwater builds up behind this frozen ice terminus until it generates sufficient pressure to lift the ice and break the bond, with a catastrophic meltwater release such as is seen with the [[Iceland]]ic [[jökulhlaup]]. As a consequence of this jökulhlaup a tunnel valley is formed.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/> :*Upglacier erosion – Wingfield proposes that tunnel valleys form gradually, with the valley head cutting progressively back toward the source up-glacier during deglaciation.<ref>Wingfield R.; The origin of major incisions within the Pleistocene deposits of the North Sea (1990) Marine Geology, 91 (1–2), pp. 31–52.</ref>
Periodic outbursts of subglacial water have been observed moving subglacial water between subglacial lakes beneath the East Antarctic Ice Sheet. Satellite data recorded a subglacial discharge totaling {{convert|2|km3|mi3|abbr=on}} traveling ~{{convert|260|km|mi|abbr=on}} over a period of less than a year. As the flow subsided, the weight of ice closed the tunnel and sealed the lake again.<ref name=Wingham2006>{{Cite journal | last = Wingham | first = Duncan J. | authorlink = | author2 = Martin J. Siegert, Andrew Shepherd and Alan S. Muir | title = Rapid discharge connects Antarctic subglacial lakes | journal = Nature | volume = 440 | issue = 7087| pages = 1033–1036 | publisher = | location = | date = 20 April 2006 | url = | issn = | pmid = 16625193| doi = 10.1038/nature04660 | id = |bibcode = 2006Natur.440.1033W | last3 = Shepherd | first3 = Andrew | last4 = Muir | first4 = Alan S. }}</ref> The water flow was modeled satisfactorily with channeling in ice and in sediment. The analytic model shows that over some regions, the ice-bedrock geometry included sections which would have frozen, blocking off flow, unless erosion of the sedimentary substrate was the means of creating a channel and sustaining the discharge.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Carter | first = Sasha P. | authorlink = | author2 = Donald D. Blankenship, Duncan A. Young. Matthew E. Peters, John W. Holt, and Martin J. Siegert | title = Dynamic distributed drainage implied by the flow evolution of the 1996–1998 Adventure Trench subglacial lake discharge | journal = Earth and Planetary Science Letters | volume = 283 | issue =1–4 | pages = 24–37 | publisher = Copyright © 2009 Elsevier B.V. | location = | date = 15 June 2009 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.epsl.2009.03.019 | id = | bibcode=2009E&PSL.283...24C| last3 = Young | first3 = Duncan A. | last4 = Peters | first4 = Matthew E. | last5 = Holt | first5 = John W. | last6 = Siegert | first6 = Martin J. }}</ref> Hence, combining this data and analysis with Icelandic jökulhlaup observations, there is experimental evidence that some form of the jökulhlaup hypothesis with features of the steady state model is correct.
===Common features of tunnel valley theories=== [[File:Lagowski Park Krajobrazowy-World Wind.jpg|thumb|280px|right|A Polish [[ribbon lake]] formed in a tunnel valley. Note the variable width and the interruption between segments of the course. There is also evidence of other sediment-filled channels adjacent to this (e.g., two smaller lakes to the right)]] Subglacial meltwater flow is common to all theories; hence a key to understanding channel formation is an understanding of subglacial meltwater flow. Meltwater may be produced on the glacier surface (supraglacially), below the glacier (basally) or both. Meltwater may flow either supraglacially or basally as well; the signatures of supraglacial and basal water flow differ with the passage zone. Supraglacial flow is similar to stream flow in all surface environments – water flows from higher areas to lower areas under the influence of gravity. Basal flow exhibits significant differences. In basal flow the water, either produced by melting at the base or drawn downward from the surface by gravity, collects at the base of the glacier in ponds and lakes in a pocket overlain by hundreds of meters of ice. If there is no surface drainage path, water from surface melting will flow downward and collect in crevices in the ice, while water from basal melting will collect under the glacier; either source will form a subglacial lake. The [[hydraulic head]] of the water collected in a basal lake will increase as water drains through the ice until the pressure grows high enough to either develop a path through the ice or to float the ice above it.<ref name=Smellie2008A/><ref name=Shaw2008/>
===Steady state theory=== Sources of water and water drainage routes through and below temperate and sub-polar glaciers are reasonably well understood and provide a basis for understanding tunnel valleys. For these glaciers, supraglacial water ponds or moves in rivers across the surface of the glacier until it drops down a vertical crevice (a [[Moulin (geology)|moulin]]) in the glacier. There it joins subglacial water created by geothermal heat; some portion of the water drains into aquifers below the glacier. Excess subglacial water that cannot drain through sediment or impermeable bedrock as groundwater, moves either through channels eroded into the bed of sediment below the glacier (called Nye channels<ref>The smaller channels, known as ''Nye channels,'' are named after British physicist [[John Nye (scientist)|John Nye]].</ref>) or through channels upward into the glacial ice (called Rothlisberger channels), eventually flowing out at the ice margin. On the simplest level, the tunnel valley can be considered a larger-scale version of these phenomena.<ref name=Eyles2006>{{Cite journal | last = Eyles | first = Nick K | title = The role of meltwater in glacial processes | journal = [[Sedimentary Geology (journal)|Sedimentary Geology]] | volume = 190 | issue = 1–4 | pages = 257–268 | publisher = | location = | date = 1 August 2006 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.sedgeo.2006.05.018 | id = |bibcode = 2006SedG..190..257E }}</ref>
Tunnel valleys or tunnel channels are produced by meltwater flows beneath glacial ice. Tunnel valleys are often buried or partially buried by sediment accumulation during periods of ice advance and retreat.<ref name=Shaw2008>{{Cite journal | last = Shaw | first = J | authorlink = | author2 = A. Pugin, R.R. Young | title = A meltwater origin for Antarctic shelf bedforms with special attention to megalineations | journal = Geomorphology | volume = 102 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 364–375 | publisher = | location = | date = 15 December 2008 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.geomorph.2008.04.005 | id = |bibcode = 2008Geomo.102..364S | last3 = Young | first3 = R. R. }}</ref>
Although attractive since it scales up the Nye channel formation which has been observed in sediments, a weakness of the steady state theory is that it requires that tunnel valleys be excavated in unconsolidated sediment, in which meltwater is initially forced through an initially narrow subglacial conduit. With progressive sediment erosion by the meltwater, ice deforms under its own weight into the cavity to creating an ever-larger tunnel valley. However the steady state theory appears not to account for erosion into bedrock, which has been extensively observed.<ref name=LeHeron2009A/>
===Jökulhlaup driven erosion=== There is evidence that meltwater discharges are episodic.<ref name=Wingham2006/> This can result because as water continues to collect, more ice is lifted, and the water moves outward in a growing under-ice lake. Areas where the ice is most easily lifted (i.e., areas with thinner overlying ice sheets) are lifted first. Hence the water may move up the terrain underlying the glacier if it moves toward areas of lower overlying ice.<ref>A [[waterbed]] analogy can be applied here – the water moves under the pressure of the overlying ice, just as it does when a mass is placed on a water bed.</ref> As water collects, additional ice is lifted until a release path is created.
If no preexisting channel is present, the water is initially released in a broad-front [[jökulhlaup]] which can have a flow front that is tens of kilometers wide, spreading out in a thin front. As the flow continues, it tends to erode the underlying materials and the overlying ice, creating a channel even as the reduced pressure allows most of the glacial ice to settle back to the underlying surface, sealing off the broad front release and channelizing the flow. The direction of the channel is defined primarily by the overlying ice thickness and secondarily by the gradient of the underlying earth, and may be observed to “run uphill” as the pressure of the ice forces the water to areas of lower ice coverage until it emerges at a glacial face. Hence the configuration of the various tunnel valleys formed by a specific glaciation provide a general mapping of the glacier thickness when the tunnel valleys were formed, particularly if the original surface relief under the glacier was limited.<ref name=Smellie2008A/><ref name=Shaw2008/>
Analyses by Piotrowski demonstrate that the annual production of water from one typical catchment of {{convert|642000000|m3|cuft|abbr=out}} would normally drain through its associated tunnel valley in less than 48 hours.<ref name=Piotrowski2009>{{Cite journal | last = Piotrowski | first = Jan A. | authorlink = | title = Subglacial hydrology in north-western Germany during the last glaciation: groundwater flow, tunnel valleys and hydrological cycles | journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 16 | issue = 2 | pages = 169–185 | publisher = | location = | year = 1997 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/S0277-3791(96)00046-7 | id = |bibcode = 1997QSRv...16..169P }}</ref> The debris found in tunnels and at the mouth of tunnels tends to be coarse rocks and boulders – this is indicative of high flow velocities and an extremely erosive environment. This erosive environment is consistent with creation of tunnels over {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep and {{convert|2.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide, as have been observed in the Antarctic.<ref name=Shaw2008/> Piotrowski’s model predicts a cycle as follows: # Meltwater is produced as a result of geothermal heating from below. Surface ablation water is not considered as it would be minimal at the glacial maximum and evidence indicates that surface water does not penetrate more than {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} into a glacier.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/> # Meltwater initially drains through subglacial aquifers.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/> # When the hydraulic transmissivity of the substratum is exceeded, subglacial meltwater accumulates in basins.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/> # Water accumulates sufficiently to open the ice blockage in the tunnel valley which accumulated after the last discharge.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/> # The tunnel valley discharges the meltwater excess – turbulent flow melts out or erodes the excess ice as well as eroding the valley floor.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/> # As the water level drops, the pressure decreases until the tunnel valleys again close with ice and water flow ceases.<ref name=Piotrowski2009/>
===Post-erosion infill processes=== Tunnel valleys have similar characteristics, irrespective of whether they are formed on land or in a submerged environment. This is because they are formed by high pressure water under a thick ice sheet – in a submerged environment they still have sufficient pressure to erode tunnel valleys into configurations comparable to those generated on land.<ref name=LeHeron2009A>{{Cite journal | last = Le Heron | first = Daniel Paul | author2 = Jonathan Craig and James L. Etienne | title = Ancient glaciations and hydrocarbon accumulations in North Africa and the Middle East | journal = Earth-Science Reviews | volume = 93 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 47–76 | publisher = © 2009 Elsevier B.V. | location = | date = April 2009 | doi =10.1016/j.earscirev.2009.02.001 | id = |bibcode = 2009ESRv...93...47L | last3 = Etienne | first3 = James L. }}</ref>
Tunnel valleys may remain open, partially filled or filled, as a function of the glacial recession. The filled configuration is significant because filled tunnel valleys become excellent reservoirs for either water (aquifer) or for oil. This results since relatively coarse-grained sandstones are located on the valley floors and valley margins and valley floor because the coarser-grained sediments settle out more easily and accumulate preferentially in the flowing water common to the tunnel valley fill stages.<ref name=LeHeron2009A/>
The subglacial tunnel valley networks originally formed near the ice margin. Tunnel valleys are likely to fill with sediment as the result of meltwater release during glacial recession. Tunnel valleys fill in two main ways. In the first instance, debris carried by flow settles out and accumulates in the tunnel valley. Subsequently, once the ice has retreated sufficiently, marine deposits may be laid down, depending on the water depth at the ice front.<ref name=LeHeron2009A/>
The tunnel valley sedimentary record is controlled by meltwater release flowrates and sediment burdens during glacial recession. The sediment found in the tunnel valley provides insight into whether it was laid down in a tidal environment, a transitional environment, or an essentially dry environment with good drainage. In the glaciomarine environment, glacially-related deposits are interbedded with to those similar to those on non-glaciated tidal areas; the tidal environment will show undertow dominated fans. The transitional environment is characterized by both mixed marine and fresh water life in a delta environment. In an essentially dry environment, the glacial flow carries sediment which accumulates much as it would in any stream bed.<ref name=LeHeron2009A/>
===Large-scale structure=== [[Ice sheet dynamics|Ice flow within glaciers]] results from an increase in the surface slope of the glacier, which result from geographic features combined with an imbalance between the amounts of ice accumulated through precipitation and lost through [[ablation]]. The increased gradient increases the [[shear stress]] on a glacier until it begins to flow. The flow velocity and deformation are also affected by the slope of the ice, the ice thickness and temperature.
Punkari identified that [[ice sheets|continental ice sheets]] typically flow in fan-shaped lobes, which converge from separate sources and move at differing speeds. Lobes are separated by [[interlobular|interlobate]] zones, which have thinner ice coverage. Water collects in this interlobate area. The hydraulic head (pressure) is lower in areas of thinner ice; hence subglacial water tends to converge on the interlobate joint. The separate lobes move at different speeds, generating friction at the ice boundary; the heat released melts ice to release additional water. The surface of the interlobate area is crevassed, allowing surface meltwater, which runs down the ice surface to the lower area, to penetrate into the ice. As a result, the ice-flow patterns and the debris accumulation are different in interlobate zones. Specifically, tunnel valleys and [[esker]]s indicate water flow toward the interlobate zones, which are elevated as the result of debris carried and deposited there.<ref name=Punkari1997>{{Cite journal | last = Punkari | first = Mikko | authorlink = | title = Glacial and Glaciofluvial Deposits in the Interlobate Areas of the Scandinavian Ice Sheet | journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 16 | issue = 7| pages = 741–753 | publisher = Elsevier Science Ltd. | location = | year = 1997 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/S0277-3791(97)00020-6| id = |bibcode = 1997QSRv...16..741P }}</ref>
==Geographic distribution== [[File:Klokkekildebakker-20010916.jpg|thumb|280px|Tunnel valley landscape from the island [[Zealand]] in [[Denmark]].]] Glacially formed tunnel valleys have been identified on every continent.
===Africa=== Tunnel valleys associated with the [[Late Ordovician]] glaciation have been observed in north [[Africa]]n countries, including [[Libya]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Le Heron | first =D.P. | authorlink = | author2 = H.A. Armstrong, C. Wilson, J.P. Howard, L. Gindre | title = Glaciation and deglaciation of the Libyan Desert: The Late Ordovician record Sedimentary Geology | journal = Sedimentary Geology | volume = 223| issue = | pages = 100| publisher = Copyright © 2009 Elsevier B.V. | location = | date = Available online 14 November 2009 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.sedgeo.2009.11.002 | id = |bibcode = 2010SedG..223..100L | last3 =Wilson | first3 =C. | last4 =Howard | first4 =J.P. | last5 =Gindre | first5 =L. }}</ref> These large-scale channel-fill sandstone bodies (tunnel valleys) are a striking sedimentological feature of the glacially related deposits on the old North [[Gondwana]]land margin. They range from {{convert|10|-|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} in depth, and {{convert|500|-|3000|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide. The tunnel valleys are incised into the bedrock and can be traced for {{convert|2|-|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} in length. In one example, in [[Mauritania]], in the western [[Sahara]], Late Ordovician [[siliciclastic]] glacial features and deposits on the North [[Gondwana]] continental shelf include incised channels identified as tunnel valleys. The filled tunnel valley are several kilometers long and several hundred meters wide. Reconstructions conclude that these structures were located in glacier ice-margin regions; the cross-sections of the valleys are comparable to those confirmed to have formed glacially, the valleys end in outwash fans similar to tunnel valleys, and the infill is post-glacial typical of that observed for tunnel valleys.<ref name= Ghienne1998>{{Cite journal | last = Ghienne | first = Jean François | author2 = John Shaw and Kenneth I. Skene | title = Large-scale channel fill structures in Late Ordovician glacial deposits in Mauritania, western Sahara | journal = Sedimentary Geology | volume = 119 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 141–159 | publisher = © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. | location = | date = July 1998 | doi =10.1016/S0037-0738(98)00045-1 | id = | bibcode=1998SedG..119..141G}}</ref>
In southern Africa a [[Permo-Carboniferous]] tunnel valley system has been identified in northern Cape Province, South Africa.<ref name = Nisser1988>J. N. J. Visser (1988). A Permo-Carboniferous tunnel valley system east of Barkly West, northern Cape Province. ''[[South African Journal of Geology]]''; September 1988; v. 91; no. 3. p. 350-357.</ref>
===Antarctica=== The active formation of tunnel valleys is observed in the present period beneath the Antarctic ice.<ref name="Smellie2008A"/><ref name="Shaw2008"/>
===Asia=== During the late [[Ordovician]], eastern [[Gondwana]] was covered with ice sheets. As a consequence, [[Jordan]] and [[Saudi Arabia]] exhibit regionally-extensive filled tunnel valley structures.<ref name=Armstrong2009/>
===Australia=== Open-pit gold mines near [[Kalgoorlie]], Western [[Australia]], expose an extensive network of glacially-eroded valleys filled with [[tillite]] and [[shale]] cut below the [[Paleozoic|Late Paleozoic]] [[Pilbara craton|Pilbara ice sheet]].<ref name=Eyles2001>{{Cite journal | last = Eyles| first = Nicholas | authorlink = |author2=Peter de Broekert | title = Glacial tunnel valleys in the Eastern Goldfields of Western Australia cut below the Late Paleozoic Pilbara ice sheet | journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology | volume = 171 | issue = 1–2 | pages = 29–40 | publisher = | location = | date = 1 July 2001 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/S0031-0182(01)00265-6 | id = | bibcode = 2001PPP...171...29E}}</ref>
===Europe=== Tunnel valleys and related glacial impacts have been identified in [[Russia]], [[Belarus]], [[Ukraine]], [[Poland]], [[Germany]], Northern [[France]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Belgium]], [[Great Britain]], [[Finland]], [[Sweden]], [[Denmark]] and [[Norway]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Baltrūnas | first = Valentinas | authorlink = | author2 = Kęstutis Švedasb and Violeta Pukelytėa | title = Palaeogeography of South Lithuania during the last ice age | journal = Sedimentary Geology | volume = 193 | issue = 1–4 | pages = 221–231 | publisher = Copyright © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. | location = | date = 1 January 2007 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.sedgeo.2005.09.024 | id = |bibcode = 2007SedG..193..221B | last3 = Pukelytė | first3 = Violeta }}</ref> They have been studied in detail in Denmark, north Germany and north Poland where the thick ice sheet of the [[Devensian glaciation|Weichsel]] and earlier [[Glaciation]]s, having flowed down from the mountains of [[Scandinavia]], began to rise up the north-European slope, driven by the altitude of the glacial ice accumulation over [[Scandinavia]]. Their alignment indicates the direction of ice flow at the time of their formation.<ref name="J"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Smolska | first = Ewa | authorlink = | title = Development of gullies and sediment fans in last-glacial areas on the example of the Suwałki Lakeland (NE Poland) | journal = CATENA | volume = 71 | issue = 1 | pages = 122–131 | publisher = | location = | date = 1 September 2007 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.catena.2006.10.009 | id = }}</ref> They are found extensively in the [[United Kingdom]] with several examples reported from [[geology of Cheshire|Cheshire]] for example.<ref name="Piotrowski2009"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last = Livingstone | title = The Brampton kame belt and Pennine escarpment meltwater channel system (Cumbria, UK): Morphology, sedimentology and formation| journal = Proceedings of the [[Geologists' Association]], in Press | volume = 70 | pages = 24 | date = Corrected Proof, Available online 24 November 2009 | first = Stephen J. |author2=David J.A. Evans |author3=Colm Ó Cofaigh |author4=Jonathan Hopkins | doi = 10.1016/j.gloplacha.2009.11.005 |bibcode = 2010GPC....70...24C | last5 = Borodavko| first5 = Pavel| last6 = Morvan| first6 = Hervé}}</ref> They are also to be found under the North Sea.<ref>Benn, D.I. and Evans, D.J.A.; Glaciers & Glaciation (1998) Oxford University Press, Inc. {{ISBN|0-340-58431-9}} Fig. 9.27</ref>
Examples of lakes formed in tunnel valleys include the [[Ruppiner See]] (a [[lake]] in [[Ostprignitz-Ruppin]], [[Brandenburg]]), the [[Werbellinsee]], and the [[Schwielochsee (lake)|Schwielochsee]], all in [[Germany]].
===North America=== [[Okanagan Lake]] is a large, deep [[ribbon lake]] in the [[Okanagan|Okanagan Valley]] of [[British Columbia]] which formed in a tunnel valley from the Okanogan lobe of the [[Cordilleran Ice Sheet]]. The lake is {{convert|135|km|mi|abbr=on}} long, between {{convert|4|and|5|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide, and has a surface area of {{convert|351|km2|mi2|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Lesemann | title = Regional reconstruction of subglacial hydrology and glaciodynamic behaviour along the southern margin of the Cordilleran Ice Sheet in British Columbia, Canada and northern Washington State, USA| journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 28| issue = 23–24| date = November 2009 | pages = 2420–2444 | first = Jerome-Etienne |author2=Tracy A. Brennand | doi = 10.1016/j.quascirev.2009.04.019|bibcode = 2009QSRv...28.2420L }}</ref> Northern [[Idaho]] and [[Montana]] show evidence of tunnel valley formation under the Purcell lobe and the Flathead Lobe of the Cordilleran Ice Sheet.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Smith | first = Larry N. | authorlink = | title = Late Pleistocene stratigraphy and implications for deglaciation and subglacial processes of the Flathead Lobe of the Cordilleran Ice Sheet, Flathead Valley, Montana, USA | journal = Sedimentary Geology | volume = 165 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 295–332 | publisher = | location = | date = 15 March 2004 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/j.sedgeo.2003.11.013 | id = |bibcode = 2004SedG..165..295S }}</ref>
Tunnel valleys/channels in southeast [[Alberta]] form an interconnected, anabranching network comprising Sage Creek, the [[Lost River (Alberta)|Lost River]] and the [[Milk River (Alberta–Montana)|Milk River]] and generally drain southeast.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Beaney | first = Claire L. | authorlink = | title = Tunnel channels in southeast Alberta, Canada: : evidence for catastrophic channelized drainage | journal = Quaternary International| volume = 90 | issue = 1 | pages = 2375–2391 | publisher = Copyright © 2002 Elsevier Science Ltd and INQUA. All rights reserved. | location = | year = 2001 | url = | issn = | doi =10.1016/S1040-6182(01)00093-3 | id = |bibcode = 2002QuInt..90...67B }}</ref>
[[File:Lake Superior bathymetry map, deepest point, trenches 2.png|thumb|Eastern part of Lake Superior [[bathymetry|bathymetric map]].<ref name="GLBathSup" /><ref name="GLOBE" /> The submerged valleys may have originated as tunnel valleys.<ref name="Wright73" /><ref name="Regis73" />]] Tunnel valleys have been observed in [[Minnesota]], [[Wisconsin]] and [[Michigan]] at the margins of the [[Laurentide Ice Sheet]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Fisher | first = Timothy G. | authorlink = |author2=Harry M. Jol |author3=Amber M. Boudreau | title = Saginaw Lobe tunnel channels (Laurentide Ice Sheet) and their significance in south-central Michigan, USA | journal = Quaternary Science Reviews | volume = 24 | issue = 22 | pages = 2375–2391 | publisher = | location = | date = November 2005 | url = | issn = | doi =10.1016/j.quascirev.2004.11.019 | id = |bibcode = 2005QSRv...24.2375F }}</ref> Examples of bedrock tunnel valleys in Minnesota include [[River Warren Falls]] and several valleys which lie deep beneath till deposited by the glaciers which created them, but can be traced in many places by the [[Chain of Lakes (Minneapolis)|Chain of Lakes]] in [[Minneapolis]] and lakes and dry valleys in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|St. Paul]].
The [[Kawartha lakes (Ontario)|Kawartha lakes]] of [[Ontario]] formed in the [[Wisconsinan glaciation|Late Wisconsinan]] glacial period. Ice melt from the [[Niagara Escarpment]] flowed through tunnel valleys beneath the ice expanded to form a west-to-east passage between the main [[Laurentide ice sheet]] and a mass of ice in the [[Lake Ontario]] basin.<ref>{{Cite journal | last =Russell | first = H. A. J. | authorlink = |author2=R. W. C. Arnott |author3=D. R. Sharpe | title = Evidence for rapid sedimentation in a tunnel channel, Oak Ridges Moraine, southern Ontario, Canada | journal = Sedimentary Geology | volume = 160 | issue = 1–3 | pages = 33–55 | publisher = | location = | date = 1 August 2003 | url = | issn = | doi =10.1016/S0037-0738(02)00335-4 | id = | bibcode=2003SedG..160...33R}}</ref>
[[Cedar Creek Canyon (Indiana)|Cedar Creek Canyon]] is a tunnel valley located in [[Allen County, Indiana]]. It is a very straight, narrow [[canyon|gorge]] about {{convert|50|to|100|ft}} deep that contains part of the lower segment of [[Cedar Creek (Indiana)|Cedar Creek]], the largest [[tributary]] of the [[St. Joseph River (Maumee River)|St. Joseph River]].
In the [[Laurentian Channel]] offshore eastern Canada, numerous tunnel valleys have been identified originating from the submerged valley of the [[St. Lawrence River]], which is also of glacial origin. Seismic reflection profiles of the fill of tunnel valleys suggest that they are of various ages, with the youngest dating from shortly after the [[Late Glacial Maximum]]. They result from erosion by sub-glacial water crossing the eastern [[Scotian Shelf]] off [[Nova Scotia]]. They originate from the Laurentian Channel south of the [[Cabot Strait]]. Additionally, seismic profiles show deeply buried [[Miocene|post-Miocene]] channels, some of which lie {{convert|1100|m|ft|abbr=on}} below modern sea level, cutting across the eastern part of the outer Laurentian Channel which have also tentatively been determined to be tunnel valleys. Seismic profiles have also mapped large tunnel valleys on Banquereau Bank and [[Sable Island|Sable Island Bank]].<ref name=Piper2006>{{Cite journal | last = Piper | first = David J.W. | author2 = John Shaw and Kenneth I. Skene | title = Stratigraphic and sedimentological evidence for late Wisconsinian sub-glacial outburst floods to Laurentian Fan | journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology | volume = 246 | issue = 1 | pages = 101–119 | publisher = © 2006 Published by Elsevier B.V | location = | date = 23 March 2007 | doi = 10.1016/j.palaeo.2006.10.029 | id = }}</ref>
===South America=== The [[Perito Moreno Glacier]] is located in the southern [[Southern Patagonian Ice Field]], terminating in [[Lake Argentino]] at {{coord|50|30|S|73|6|W}}. It divides Lake Argentino into the Los Témpanos channel, and the Rico branch, blocking the channel and forming an ice dam. Lake Argentino periodically breaks through in outburst floods with drainage initially through a tunnel with subsequent roof collapse to form an open channel.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Depetris | first = P.J. | authorlink = |author2=A.I. Pasquini | title = The hydrological signal of the Perito Moreno Glacier damming of Lake Argentino (southern Andean Patagonia): the connection to climate anomalies | journal = Global and Planetary Change | volume = 26 | issue = 4 | pages = 367–374 | publisher = Copyright © 2000 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.| location = | date = 15 December 2000 | url = | issn = | doi = 10.1016/S0921-8181(00)00049-7 | id = |bibcode = 2000GPC....26..367D }}</ref>
==Temporal distribution== There have been five known [[ice age]]s in the Earth's history; the Earth is experiencing the [[Quaternary glaciation|Quaternary Ice Age]] during the present time. Tunnel valleys formed during four of the five have been identified.
{| class="wikitable" ! Name ! Period ([[Year#SI prefix multipliers|Ma]]) ! Period ! Era !Tunnel valleys and tunnel valley formation extensively observed |- | [[Quaternary glaciation|Quaternary]] | 2.58 – Present | [[Neogene]] | [[Cenozoic]] | Tunnel valleys formation has been reported in northern Asia, Europe, North America, and Antarctica |- | [[Karoo Ice Age|Karoo]] | 360–260 | [[Carboniferous]] and [[Permian]] | [[Paleozoic]] |Tunnel valleys has been reported in the Carboniferous–Permian glacial record of Australia<ref name=LeHeron2009A/><ref name=Eyles2001/> and of South Africa.<ref name = Nisser1988/> |- | [[Andean-Saharan glaciation|Andean-Saharan]] | 450–420 | [[Ordovician]] and [[Silurian]] | [[Paleozoic]] |Tunnel valleys have been reported in Jordan, Saudi Arabia, [[Mauritania]], [[Mali]], [[Morocco]], [[Algeria]], Libya, [[Tunisia]], [[Niger]], [[Chad]], and [[Sudan]].<ref name=LeHeron2009A/> |- | [[Cryogenian]]<BR>(or Sturtian-Varangian) || 800–635 | [[Cryogenian]] | [[Neoproterozoic]] | Tunnel valleys have been reported in the Cryogenian strata of Oman and Mauritania.<ref name=LeHeron2009A/> |- | [[Huronian glaciation|Huronian]] || 2100–2400 | [[Siderian]] and [[Rhyacian]] | [[Paleoproterozoic]] | |}

{{other people||Yves Fortier (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Yves Fortier | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = <!--(as myimage.jpg, no 'File:')--> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name=Yves Oscar Fortier | birth_date = {{Birth date |1914|8|17}} | birth_place = [[Quebec City, Quebec]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|08|19|1914|08|17}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = geology | workplaces = [[Geological Survey of Canada]] | alma_mater = [[Laval University]], [[McGill University]] [[Stanford University]], [[Queen's University]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Logan Medal]], [[Massey Medal]] | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Yves Oscar Fortier''', [[Order of Canada|OC]], [[Royal Society of Canada|FRSC]] (August 17, 1914 – August 19, 2014) was a [[Canadian]] [[geologist]].<ref>[https://www.google.ca/search?q=Yves+Fortier+1914&oq=Yves+Fortier+1914&aqs=chrome.0.69i57j69i62.919j0&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#tbm=bks&sclient=psy-ab&q=%22Quebec+City+in+1914%2C+attended+Laval%2C+Queen+s%2C**%22&oq=%22Quebec+City+in+1914%2C+attended+Laval%2C+Queen+s%2C**%22&gs_l=serp.3...6861.7576.4.7871.4.4.0.0.0.0.74.286.4.4.0....0.0..1c.1j2.20.psy-ab.N7d_aZkEKt8&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_qf.&bvm=bv.49967636%2Cd.cGE%2Cpv.xjs.s.en_US.jOYpRJj4zMA.O&fp=fa43f706db0a825b&biw=1429&bih=678 Canadian Geographic Journal]</ref> He was the director of the [[Geological Survey of Canada]] from 1964 to 1973. He led expeditions to the [[Canadian Arctic]] in the 1950s and 1960s which identified significant potential oil and gas resources. He died at the age of 100 on August 19, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title = YVES OSCAR FORTIER (1914 - 2014)|newspaper = [[The Globe and Mail]]|date = 2014-08-23|url = http://v1.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/Deaths.20140823.93348189/BDAStory/BDA/deaths|accessdate = 2014-09-13}}</ref>
==Honours== *1953 - ''Fellow'' of the [[Royal Society of Canada]] *1964 - [[Massey Medal]], [[Royal Canadian Geographical Society]] *1974 - [[Logan Medal]], [[Geological Association of Canada]] *1980 - ''Officer'' of the [[Order of Canada]] *The mineral [[Yofortierite]] was named in his honor by Canadian geologist [[Guy Perrault]], F.R.S. (1927–2002). *The [[Yves Fortier Earth Science Journalism Award]] is also named in his honor.
